「To love the people and govern the state,
To govern the self—
Receiving *qi* preserves the body whole.
To govern the state—
Loving the people secures the realm’s peace.
Can you be without action?
To govern the self—
Breathing *jingqi* [精气], without letting it be heard by the ears.
To govern the state—
Dispensing virtue and benevolence, without letting the people below know of it.
The Celestial Gate opens and shuts—
The Celestial Gate, the North Pole’s Purple Forbidden Enclosure [北极紫微宫].
Opening and shutting, the five phases of beginning and end.
The Celestial Gate of governing the self refers to the nostrils—
Opening means panting,
Shutting means breathing.
Can you be without duality?
To govern the self, one should be like the female and male—
Stable, tranquil, soft, and weak.
To govern the state, one adapts to circumstances—
Harmonious yet not boastful.

Illuminating and far-reaching—
The Dao is clear as the sun and moon,
Fourfold and boundless beyond the eight extremes of the world.
Thus it is said:
*"To see yet not be seen,
To hear yet not be heard,
To manifest in all ten directions,
Resplendent and radiant beyond measure."*
Can you be without knowing?
There is none who can know the Dao’s fulfillment throughout the world.

Nurturing and sustaining—
The Dao generates all things and sustains them.
Generating yet not possessing—
The Dao generates all things, yet takes none for itself.
Acting yet not relying—
The Dao’s deeds are done without expectation of reward.
Lengthening yet not slaughtering—
The Dao nourishes all things without carving or using them as tools.
This is called *xuande* [profound virtue].
The Dao’s virtue is profound and dark,
Desiring to make people know it yet unseen.

The Tenth Principle of Non-Utilization
Thirty spokes join one hub—
Ancient chariots had thirty spokes,
A measure of the moon’s cycles.
All spokes converge at a single hub,
For the hub has a hollow core,
And thus the spokes gather around it.
To govern the self, one must purge emotions and desires,
Empty the five *zang* [内脏],
So that the spirit may return.
When the hub is hollow, the chariot’s function is fulfilled;
When the self is emptied, its purpose is realized.
The hub’s emptiness allows the wheels to turn;
The center’s void lets the carriage bear its load.
Molding clay to make vessels—
*Bing* [埏] means blending,
*Zhi* [埴] means earth.
Blending earth to craft utensils for food and drink.
When the vessel is hollow, its use is fulfilled;
The vessel’s emptiness allows it to receive.
Piercing doors and windows to make a dwelling—
To construct rooms and houses.
When the dwelling is hollow, its use is fulfilled.
The doors and windows’ emptiness lets people enter and exit;
The dwelling’s emptiness lets people reside within.
Thus, having is for utility—
*Li* [利], meaning "things."
Things manifest in use—
The vessel contains objects,
The dwelling holds people,
Yet fear that the house may be destroyed;
Fear that the body’s spirit may perish.
The principle of non-utilization—
The hollow void alone can embrace all forms.
Thus it is said:
*"The empty and the void can govern the having and the form."*
The Dao is the empty and the void.

The Eleventh Principle of Restrained Desire
The five colors blind the eyes—
Lusting after the five colors,
The vital essence is drained, and clarity is lost;
One cannot perceive the colorless.
The five tones deaf the ears—
Enjoying the five tones,
The harmonious *qi* departs the heart,
And one cannot hear the soundless.
The five flavors dull the palate—
*Shuang* [爽], meaning "to lose."
Indulging in the five flavors,
One loses the Dao’s true taste.
Chasing and hunting in the fields cause the mind to go mad—
The spirit prefers tranquility;
Excessive movement scatters the essence,
Thus the mind goes mad.
Hard-to-obtain treasures bring hindrance to conduct—
*Fang* [妨], meaning "to harm."
Gold, silver, jade, and pearls—
The heart is burdened by greed,
Ignorant of contentment,
And thus one’s actions harm the body and bring disgrace.
Therefore, the sage governs the belly—
Guarding the five *xing* [性],
Discarding the six *qing* [情],
Moderating the will,
Nurturing the spirit and clarity.
Not the eyes—
The eyes do not gaze wantonly,
For wanton gazing drains the essence outward.
Thus, discard that and take this—
Discard the eyes’ wanton gazing,
Take the belly’s spirit-nurturing.
The Thirteenth Principle of Satiety and Shame
Honor and disgrace like a startling alarm—
To be honored is to be startled,
To be disgraced is to be startled.
Great calamities are feared like they touch the self—
*Gui* [贵], meaning "to revere."
*Ran* [患], meaning "calamity."
When great calamities approach the self,
Thus one is startled.
What is meant by honor and disgrace?
Asking what is honor, what is disgrace.
Honor is dignity and glory,
Disgrace is shame and debasement.
To receive honor and glory like a startling alarm—
To attain high station is to be startled,
As if standing at the edge of danger.
Wealth does not dare to be extravagant,
Status does not dare to be arrogant.
To lose honor and glory like a startling alarm—
To lose favor is to be disgraced,
And one is startled by fear that calamity will return.
This is called *"honor and disgrace like a startling alarm."*

To resolve the above—
To receive honor and glory like a startling alarm,
To lose it like a startling alarm.
What is meant by *"great calamities are feared like they touch the self"*?
Returning to the question—
My great calamity arises from my having a self.
My great calamity arises from my having a self.
Having a self brings worry of toil,
Reflection on hunger and cold.
Indulging in emotions and desires,
Then calamity befalls.
When I have no self,
What calamity do I have?
If I have no self,
My body aligns with the Dao naturally—
Lightly ascending to the clouds,
Entering and exiting without obstruction,
Communing with the Dao’s spirit,
What calamity could there be?
Thus, the noble who values the self above the world
Can entrust themselves to the world—
The ruler holds their self in high regard,
Yet devalues the people,
Desiring to be the world’s master,
And thus can rely on the world yet not be trusted.
The loving who values the self above the world
Can entrust the world to themselves—
The ruler who loves their self,
Not for themselves alone,
But as the parent of all people,
With this virtue as the world’s sovereign,
Can entrust their self to the people above,
Enduring no blame for long.

The Fourteenth Principle of Praising the Profound
*"To see yet not be seen"* is called *yi* [夷]—
The colorless is *yi*.
The Dao is without hue,
And thus cannot be seen.
*"To hear yet not be heard"* is called *xi* [希]—
The soundless is *xi*.
The Dao is without sound,
And thus cannot be heard.
*"To grasp yet not obtain"* is called *wei* [微]—
The formless is *wei*.
The Dao is without substance,
And thus cannot be seized.»

chunks.original_text: 此三者不可致诘， 三者，夷、希、微也。 不可致诘者，谓无色，无声，无形，口不能言，书不能传，受之以静，求之以神，不可诘问而能得也。 故混而为一。 混，合也。 故三名合而为一。 其上不皦， 言一在天上，不昧昧光明，上下无穷极也。 其下不昧。 言一在天下，不昧昧有所暗冥。 绳绳兮不可名， 绳绳者，动行无穷极也。 不可名者，非一色也，不可以青黄赤白黑别也。 非一声也，不可以宫商角征羽听也。 非一形也，不可以长短小大度也。 复归於无物。 物，质也。 物当归之以无质。 是谓无状之状， 言一无形状，而能为万物作形状。 无物之象， 一无物质，而为万物设形象。 是谓忽恍。 言一忽忽恍恍，若存若亡，不可得见。 迎之不见其首， 一无端末，不可预待也。 除情去欲，一自归之#11。 随之不见其后。 言一无影迹，不可得而见。 执古之道，以御今之有， 圣人执古之道，生一以御万物，知今当有一也。 以知古始，是谓道纪。 人能知上古本始有一，是谓知道之纪纲也。 显德第十五 古之善为士者， 谓得道之君也。 微妙玄通， 玄，天也。 言其志节玄妙，精与天通。 深不可识。 道德深远，不可识知。 内视如盲，反听若聋，莫知所长。 夫唯不可识，故强为之容： 谓下句也。 豫兮若冬涉川， 举事辄加重慎，豫豫兮若冬涉川，心难之。 犹兮若畏四邻， 其进犹犹若拘制，若人犯法，畏四邻之知。 俨兮其若客， 如客对主人，俨然无所造作也。 涣兮若冰之将释， 涣者，解散也。 释者，消亡也。 谓除情去欲，日以空虚也。 敦兮其若朴， 敦者，质厚也。 朴者，形未分也。 内守精神，外无文彩。 旷兮其若谷， 旷者，宽大也。 谷者#12，空虚。 不有德功名，无所不包也。 浑兮其若浊。 浑者，守本真也。 浊者，不昭然也。 与众合同不自尊。 孰能浊以止静之，徐清？ 孰，谁也。 谁能如水之浊，止而静之，徐徐而自清。 孰能安以久动之，徐生？ 谁能安静以久，徐徐以长生也。 保此道者，不欲盈。 保此长生之道，不欲奢泰盈溢。 夫唯不盈，故能弊不新成。 夫唯不盈满之人，能守弊，不为新成。 守弊者，匿光荣也#13。 新成者，贵功名也。 归根第十六 致虚极， 致，至也。 道人捐情去欲，五藏清静，至於虚极也。 守静笃。 守清静，行笃厚。 万物并作， 作，生也。 万物并生。 吾以是观其复。 言吾以观万物无不皆归其本也，人当重其本。 夫物芸芸， 芸芸者，花叶茂盛之貌。 各复归其根。 言万物无不枯落，反复其根而更生。 归根曰静， 静谓根也。 根安静柔弱，谦卑处下，故不复死。 静曰复命， 言能安静者，是谓复还性命，便不死。 复命曰常， 复命使不死，乃道之所常行也。 知常曰明。 能知道之所常行者，则为明也。 不知常，妄作，凶。 不知道之所常行，而妄作巧诈，则失神明而凶。 知常容， 能知道之所常行，则除情欲，无所不包容也。 容乃公， 无所不包容，则公正无私，众邪莫当。 公乃王， 公正无私，则可以为天下王，治身正则，形一而静，神明千万，共凑己躬。 王乃天， 能王则德洽，神明乃与天通矣。 天乃道， 德与天通，则与道合同也。 道乃久。 与道合同乃能长久。 没身不殆。 能公能王，通天合道，四者纯备，道德弘远，无殃无咎，乃与天地同没，终不危殆也。

---

This triad cannot be questioned or examined,
Three things: *yi* [夷], *xi* [希], and *wei* [微].
That which cannot be questioned or examined—
It is the colorless, the soundless, the formless.
The mouth cannot speak of it,
The written word cannot transmit it.
Received in stillness, sought with the spirit,
It cannot be questioned yet is known.

Thus, it blends into oneness.
*Hun* [混] means to merge.
Therefore, the three names unite as one.
Above, it shines without brightness—
The one in the heavens,
Not dimly luminous, yet boundless above and below.
Below, it is without obscurity—
The one in the world,
Not dimly veiled in darkness or hidden depths.

It flows ceaselessly, yet cannot be named—
*Shuangshuang* [绳绳], ceaseless motion.
It cannot be named,
Not a single hue—
Not distinguishable by blue, yellow, red, white, or black.
Not a single sound—
Not discerned by the five tones of *gōng* [宫], *shāng* [商], *jué* [角], *zhǐ* [征], or *yǔ* [羽].
Not a single form—
Not measured by length, shortness, smallness, or greatness.
Returning to the formless.

*Wu* [物] means substance.
Substance must return to the formless.
This is called the *state* [状] of the formless—
The one without form yet able to shape all things.
The *image* [象] of the formless—
The one without substance yet able to manifest all forms.
This is called *hūhuǎng* [忽恍]—
The one that is indistinct, as if present or absent,
Unseen.

To meet it, you cannot see its beginning—
The one without start or end,
Unpredictable.
To abandon passions and desires,
The one returns to itself#11.

To follow it, you cannot see its trace—
The one without shadow or mark,
Unseen.
To hold the ancient Dao,
And thus govern the present—
The sage grasps the ancient Dao,
Generates the one to govern all things,
Knows that the present must also return to the one.
To know the ancient origin,
This is called the *Dao*’s *jì* [纪].

If one can know the ancient origin of the one,
This is called knowing the *Dao*’s fundamental threads.
**The Fifteenth Principle of Manifesting Virtue**

The ancient adept at being a *shì* [士]—
The ruler who obtained the Dao.
Subtle and profound, penetrating the heavens,
Heavenly [玄] refers to the Dao.
Their resolve and conduct are profound and subtle,
Their spirit in harmony with the Dao.
Deep beyond recognition.

Virtue and power are profound and distant,
Beyond recognition.
Internally, they see as if blind,
They turn and hear as if deaf,
None know their excellence.

Only because it cannot be recognized,
They forcefully assume its guise—
That is to say: the following lines.

*Yù* [豫]—like winter crossing a river,
Cautious and deliberate in all actions,
*Yùyù* [豫豫]—like winter crossing a river,
Their heart finds it difficult.
*Yóu* [犹]—like fearing the four neighbors,
Their advance is hesitant, as if restrained,
Like one who has broken the law,
Feared for the four neighbors’ judgment.
*Yǎn* [俨]—like a guest,
As a guest before their host,
They are dignified yet unassuming.
*Huàn* [涣]—like ice about to dissolve,
*Huàn* means to disperse,
*Shì* [释] means to vanish,
That is to say: abandoning passions and desires,
Daily emptiness.
*Dūn* [敦]—like undifferentiated simplicity,
*Dūn* means solid and thick,
*Pǔ* [朴] means unrefined form,
Internally guarding the spirit,
Externally without ornamentation.
*Kuàng* [旷]—like a valley,
*Kuàng* means vast and spacious,
A *gǔ* [谷]#12 is emptiness,
Without virtue, achievement, or name,
Yet encompassing all.
*Hún* [浑]—like turbid water,
*Hún* means to preserve their true nature,
Turbid [浊] means not clearly evident,
In harmony with the common yet not self-exalted.

Who can, like turbid water,
Cease and settle, then gradually clear?
Who can, with stillness,
Endure motion for long, then gradually arise?

Those who preserve this Dao
Do not desire excess.
Preserving this Dao of longevity,
They do not desire indulgence or overflow.
Only because they do not overflow,
They can endure wear without renewal.

Only those who do not overflow
Can guard against decay,
Hiding their brilliance.
Renewal means valuing achievement and name.

**The Sixteenth Principle of Returning to the Root**

Reach the utmost emptiness—
*Zhì* [致] means to attain.
The Daoist abandons passions and desires,
The five *zàng* [藏] organs are pure and still,
Attaining the utmost emptiness.
Guard steadfast stillness—
Guard purity and stillness,
Practice with sincerity and depth.

All things arise together—
*Zuò* [作] means to generate.
All things generate together.
With this, I observe their return.

That is to say: I observe all things
Returning to their origin,
Humans must cherish their root.

Things are abundant and flourishing—
*Yún yún* [芸芸], the appearance of blossoms and leaves.
Each returns to its root.
That is to say: all things
Without fail wither and fall,
Returning to their root to regenerate.
Returning to the root is called stillness—
Stillness refers to the root.
The root is tranquil, soft, and weak,
Humble and lowly, thus it does not die again.
Stillness is called returning to *mìng* [命]—
To be able to remain tranquil
Is called returning to one’s original nature and vitality,
Thus one does not die.
Returning to *mìng* is called *cháng* [常]—
Returning to *mìng* prevents death,
This is the Dao’s eternal practice.
Knowing *cháng* is called *míng* [明]—
To know the Dao’s eternal practice
Is called enlightenment.
Not knowing *cháng*, yet acting arbitrarily,
Is perilous.
Knowing *cháng*, one is inclusive—
To know the Dao’s eternal practice,
One abandons passions and desires,
Embracing all without exception.

To embrace is to be impartial—
Without exception, one is impartial and just,
All evils cannot withstand.
Impartiality is called *wáng* [王]—
Impartial and just,
One can rule the world,
Correcting the body’s essence,
Form unified and still,
Spirit enlightened for myriad ages,
All converging within oneself.
*Wáng* is called *tiān* [天]—
To rule is to harmonize with virtue,
Spirit enlightened now communicates with heaven.
Heaven is called *Dào* [道]—
Virtue harmonizes with heaven,
Thus it unites with the Dao.
The Dao is called *jiǔ* [久]—
To unite with the Dao is to endure.
To perish without harm—
To be impartial, to rule,
Harmonizing with heaven and uniting with the Dao,
All four perfected,
Virtue and power vast and distant,
No misfortune or blame,
Thus one perishes with heaven and earth,
Never in peril.

chunks.original_text: 淳风第十七 太上，下知有之。 太上谓太古无名号之君。 下知有之者，下知上有君，而不臣事，质朴也。 其次，亲而誉之。 其德可见，恩惠可称，故亲爱而誉之。 其次，畏之。 设刑法以治也。 其次，侮之。 禁多令烦，不可归诚，故欺侮之。 有不足焉， 君信不足於下，下则欺诈於上。 有不信焉。 君信不足於下，下则应之以不信而欺其君。 犹兮其贵言。 说太古之君，举事犹犹，贵重於言，恐离道失自然也。 功成事遂， 谓天下太平。 百姓皆谓我自然。 百姓不知君上之德淳厚，反以为己自当然#1。 俗薄第十八 大道废，有仁义。 大道之时，家有孝子，国有忠信，仁义不#2见。 大道废不用，而恶逆生，乃有仁义可传道。 智慧出，有大伪。 智慧之君贱德贵言，贱质贵文，下则应之以大伪奸诈。 六亲不和，有孝慈。 六亲绝，亲戚不和，乃有孝慈相牧养。 国家昏乱，有忠臣。 政令不行，上下相怨，邪辟争权，乃有忠臣匡救其君也。 此言天下太平不知仁，人尽无欲不知康，各洁己不知贞。 故大道之世，孝慈灭，仁义没，犹日月盛明，众星失光。 还淳第十九 绝圣
chunks.translated_text:
**17. The Primordial Wind:**
The Most High, the lowest know of His existence.
The Most High refers to the sovereign of the primordial age, before names were given.
The lowest know of His existence yet do not serve Him—this is the simplicity of the unrefined.

The next stage: they are close to Him and praise Him.
His virtue is visible, His benevolence and grace are worthy of praise,
so they love and honor Him.

The next stage: they fear Him.
He governs through laws and punishments.

The next stage: they scorn Him.
He imposes many prohibitions, causing confusion,
and they cannot be brought to sincerity, so they deceive and mock Him.

If this is insufficient:
When the sovereign’s trust is lacking among the people,
the people then deceive and betray him above.
If this is untrustworthy:
When the sovereign’s trust is lacking among the people,
the people respond with their own lack of trust and deceive their sovereign.

Thus, the Most High values speech.
The sovereign of the primordial age acted with restraint,
valuing speech above all else,
for fear of straying from the Dao and losing naturalness.

When achievements are complete and affairs settled,
the world is in great peace.
The people all say, "This is natural."
The people do not know that the sovereign’s virtue is pure and profound,
but instead take it as their own inherent nature.

**18. The Crassness of Custom:**
When the Great Dao is abandoned, there arises benevolence and righteousness.
In the age of the Great Dao,
families had filial children, states had loyal and trustworthy subjects,
and benevolence and righteousness were not yet seen.
When the Great Dao is abandoned and not practiced,
evil and perversity arise,
and then benevolence and righteousness can be transmitted as the Dao.

When wisdom appears, there arises great deceit.
The wise sovereigns devalue virtue and exalt speech,
devalue simplicity and exalt ornamentation,
and the people respond with great deceit and cunningness.

When the six bonds of kinship are severed, there arises filial piety and kindness.
When the six bonds of kinship are broken and relatives do not harmonize,
then filial piety and kindness arise to nurture and care for them.

When the state is in chaos and confusion, there arise loyal ministers.
When governance fails and orders are not followed,
the ruler and subjects blame each other,
while the wicked vie for power,
then loyal ministers arise to rectify their sovereign.

This is to say:
In the age of the Great Dao, the people do not know benevolence,
when desires are fully satisfied, they do not know contentment,
when each purifies themselves, they do not know integrity.
Thus, in the age of the Great Dao,
filial piety and kindness vanish,
benevolence and righteousness fade away—
just as the sun and moon shine brightly,
while the stars lose their luster.

**19. Reverting to Simplicity:**
Abandon the Sage...

Abandon the Sage’s artifices, return to the origin, and uphold the primal Way.
The Five Emperors drew symbols, and Cang Jie created writing—
yet this was not as effective as the Three Sovereigns’ knotted cords,
which governed without scripture.

Abandon wisdom,
abandon cleverness and cunning,
return to non-action.
The people’s benefits multiply a hundredfold;
agriculture thrives, and public affairs are without private gain.

Abandon benevolence and righteousness,
abandon the cleverness that sees benevolence,
abandon the ostentation that values righteousness.
The people return to filial piety and kindness—
for virtue’s transformation is pure.

Abandon artifice.
Those who abandon artifice prevent deceit from corrupting truth.
Abandon profit,
block the paths of greed, and close the gates of power.
Thieves and robbers vanish.
The ruler’s transformation is public and just,
and the people below have no private deceit.
These three are called the three uppermost affairs to abandon.

Because scripture is insufficient,
because scripture is insufficient to transform the people,
therefore let governance have its proper place.
As the following verse states:

Embrace simplicity and preserve purity—
to embrace simplicity is to hold fast to simplicity and truth,
not to value ornamentation.
To preserve purity is to manifest one’s natural sincerity to the world,
so that it may be emulated.
Fewer private interests, fewer desires.
To have fewer private interests is to correct the absence of private gain.
To have fewer desires is to know contentment.

Abandon learning.

chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter 20: Divergent Customs** (continued)

Abandon learning without attaining truth—
this does not align with the **Dao/Way** and its teachings.
Be free from worries.
Eliminate superficiality and extravagance, then there will be no worries.

What is the difference between *Zhi* and *A*?
Both are responses to the times,
yet their difference is vast.

The rulers of our age despise genuine virtue
and exalt mere ornamentation.
How far apart are good and evil?
The good are praised,
the evil are rebuked—
how can they truly be distinguished?

The rulers of our age prefer treacherous flatterers
to loyal and upright ministers.
What is it that people fear?
People fear the **Dao/Way** of the learned.
What they truly fear is the ruler who does not abandon learning.
One must indeed fear this.

The current rulers favor superficial display,
slaying the virtuous and the wise.
Oh, the chaos—
it knows no end!

Speaking of the vulgar masses,
they pursue learning only to indulge in empty ornamentation#3,
yet their corruption cannot be halted.

The common people revel in excess,
in licentiousness and indulgence,
in boundless desires.
Like feasting on the **Tailao** sacrificial offerings,
they crave abundance as if starving,
yet their hunger is never satisfied.
Like ascending a terrace in spring,
spring, when *yin* and *yang* intermingle,
and all things are stirred—
to stand upon the terrace and gaze,
their minds overflow with wantonness.

Yet I alone stand in dread,
without any sign of desire.
Like an infant before it speaks,
or a younger sibling unable yet to answer others.
I drift, drifting—
as if without destination.

I drift like one lost in the remote wilderness,
with nowhere to turn.
While others have abundance,
others hoard wealth to indulge in luxury,
and excess knowledge to deceive with.
I alone seem cast aside,
as though lacking—
my heart is that of a simpleton.

I do not conform to the world,
steadfast in the One, unmoved,
like the heart of a simpleton.

Pure and unadulterated—
without distinction or division.
The common people are bright and clear,
illuminated and discerning.

chunks.original_text: 我独若昏； 如暗昧也。 众人察察， 急且疾也。 我独闷闷。 闷闷，无所截割。 忽兮若海， 我独忽忽兮如江海之流，莫知其所穷极。 漂兮若无所止。 我独漂漂若飞若扬，无所止也，志意在神域。 众人皆有以， 以有为也。 而我独顽 我独无为。 似鄙。 鄙似若不逮也。 我独异於人， 与人异。 而贵食母。 食，用也。 母，道也。 唯我独贵用道。 虚心第二十一 孔德之容， 孔，大也。 有大德之人无所不容，能受垢浊，处谦冲。 唯道是从。 唯，独也。 大德之人不随世俗所行，独从於道也。 道之为物，唯恍唯忽。 道之於万物，独恍忽往来而无所定。 恍兮忽兮，其中有物； 道唯恍忽，其中有一。 经营生化，因气立质。 忽兮恍兮，其中有象； 道唯窈冥无形，其中独有万物法象。 窈兮冥兮，其中有精； 道唯窈冥，其中有精实，神明相薄，阴阳交会之。 其精甚真， 言道精气神妙甚真，非有饰也。 其中有信。 道匿功藏名，信在其中。 自古及今，其名不去， 自，从也。 从古至今，道常在不去。 以阅众甫。 阅，禀也。 甫，始也。 言道禀万物始生，从道受气。 吾何以知众甫之然哉？ 以此#4。

I alone seem dim—
as though in darkness.
Others are keen and sharp,
urgent and swift.

I alone am murky—
murky, without division or separation.
Vast as the sea,
I alone drift, drifting—
like the ebb and flow of rivers and oceans,
unknown in their depths.

I drift—
drifting like windborne dust or lifted feathers,
without end,
my will and intent in the realm of the spirit.

Others all have *doings*—
they cling to action.
Yet I alone am obstinate,
I alone do nothing,
seeming crude.
Crude, as though inadequate.

I alone differ from others,
differing from the crowd,
yet I alone honor the *Mother*.
*Mother*—the Dao.
Only I alone honor the Dao’s use.

**Chapter Twenty-One: The Virtue of the Hollow**

The bearing of great virtue—
great, vast—
one of great virtue contains all,
able to receive filth and turbidity,
dwelling in humility and openness.
Only the Dao is followed.
Only—uniquely—
one of great virtue does not conform to worldly ways,
but follows the Dao alone.

The Dao, as a thing,
is only vague and indistinct.
The Dao, toward all things,
uniquely drifts and vanishes,
without fixed form.

Vague, indistinct—
yet within it, there is substance.
The Dao is only vague and indistinct,
yet within it, there is the One.

It nurtures and transforms life,
establishing form through *qi*.
Indistinct, vague—
yet within it, there are patterns.
The Dao is only profound and formless,
yet within it, the laws of all things reside.

Profound, dark—
yet within it, there is essence.
The Dao is only profound and dark,
yet within it lies the true essence,
where divine and mortal intermingle,
where *yin* and *yang* converge.
Its essence is most true—
the Dao’s essence, *qi*, and spirit are most wondrous and true,
without ornamentation.
Within it, there is sincerity.
The Dao conceals its deeds and hides its name,
yet sincerity abides within.

From ancient times to now,
its name does not fade—
from, since.
Since ancient times to now, the Dao remains ever-present.
It nourishes all beginnings.
*Nourishes*—receives.
*Beginnings*—origins.
How do I know all things begin thus?
By this.

chunks.original_text: 益谦第二十二 曲则全， 曲己从众，不自专，则全。 枉则直， 枉，屈也。 屈己而伸人，久久而自得直已。 窊则盈， 地窊下，水归之。 人谦下，德归之。 弊则新， 自受弊薄，后己先人，天下敬之，久久自新之也。 少则得， 自受少则得多也。 天道佑谦，鬼神益虚。 多则惑。 财多者，惑於所守。 学多者，惑於所闻。 是以圣人抱一为天下式。 抱，守也。 式，法也。 圣人守一乃知万事，故能为天下之法式。 不自见，故明； 圣人不以其目视千里之外，乃因天下之目以视，故能明达。 不自是，故彰； 圣不自以为是而非人，故能彰显於世矣。 不自伐，故有功； 伐，取也。 圣人德化流行，不自取其美，故有功於天下。 不自矜，故长。 矜，大也。 圣人不自贵大，故能长久不危。 夫唯不争#5，故天下莫能与之争。 此言天下贤与不肖，无能与不争者争。 古之所谓曲则全者，岂虚言哉。 传古言曲从则全，正言非虚也。 故诚全而归之。 诚，实也。 能行曲从者，实其肌体，归之於父母，无有伤害也。 虚无第二十三 希言自然。

The **Benef of Modesty** (Chapter 22)

If one bends, one is whole.
Bend oneself to follow the multitude,
do not assert oneself alone—
then one remains whole.

If one is crooked, one becomes straight.
Crooked—bent.
Bending oneself while extending to others,
over time, one naturally attains straightness for oneself.

If one is lowly, one is filled.
The earth is lowly and deep; water flows to it.
Humility in a person—
virtue flows to them.

If one is afflicted, one is renewed.
When one bears hardship lightly,
puts others before oneself,
the world respects them—
over time, one renews oneself.

If one is few, one gains much.
When one receives little,
one obtains much in return.

The Dao favors the modest,
the spirits and *qi* benefit the humble.
Excess leads to confusion.
Those with much wealth—
confused by what they must guard.
Those with much learning—
confused by what they must hear.

Thus, the Sage embraces unity as a model for all under heaven.
Embrace—guard.
Model—law.
The Sage guards unity,
knowing all things,
thus able to serve as the law for all under heaven.

Not self-assertive, hence clear.
The Sage does not use his own eyes to see beyond a thousand *li*,
but relies on the eyes of all under heaven to see,
thus able to perceive and reach far.

Not self-righteous, hence illustrious.
The Sage does not assume his own correctness while rejecting others,
thus able to shine brightly in the world.

Not self-praising, hence meritorious.
Praise—take.
The Sage’s virtue spreads naturally,
not taking credit for his own excellence,
thus his merit is recognized by all under heaven.

Not self-glorifying, hence enduring.
Glorify—magnify.
The Sage does not magnify his own greatness,
thus able to endure without peril.

Only by not striving,
does the world find none who can contend with them.
This means that all under heaven—
whether virtuous or unvirtuous—
none can contend with those who do not strive.

The ancients spoke of *"bending brings wholeness"*—
was this mere empty talk?
Passed-down words: *"Bend and follow, and one is whole,"*
proven true.
Thus, sincerity is whole and returns to its source.
Sincerity—reality.
Those who can practice bending and following—
their bodies are unharmed,
returning to their parents,
without injury.

The **Vacuity of Nonbeing** (Chapter 23)

Rarely spoken of—
nature’s spontaneity.
chunks.overlap_context:
ngle,
where *yin* and *yang* converge.
Its essence is most true—
the Dao’s essence, *qi*, and spirit are most wondrous and true,
without ornamentation.
Within it, there is sincerity.
The Dao conceals its deeds and hides its name,
yet sincerity abides within.

From ancient times to now,
its name does not fade—
from, since.
Since ancient times to now, the Dao remains ever-present.
It nourishes all beginnings.
*Nourishes*—receives.
*Beginnings*—origins.
How do I know all things begin thus?
By this.

chunks.original_text: 希言谓爱言也。 爱言者，自然之道。 飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日。 飘风，疾风也。 骤雨，暴雨也。 疾不能长，暴不能久也。 孰为此者？ 天地。 谁为此飘风暴雨者？ 天地所为也。 天地尚不能久， 不能终朝至夕。 而况於人乎？ 天地至神，合为飘风暴雨，尚不能使从朝至暮，何况於人而欲慕卒乎？ 故从事於道者， 从，为也。 人为事，当如道安静，不当如飘风暴雨。 道者同於道， 道者，谓好道之人。 同於道者，所为与道同也。 德者同於德， 德者，有德之人也。 同於德者，所为与德同也。 失者同於失。 失谓自任己而失人也。 同於失者，谓所为与失同。 同於道者，道亦乐得之； 同於德者，德亦乐得之； 同於失者，失亦乐得之。 信不足焉， 君信不足于下，下则应之以不信。 有不信焉。 此言物类相归也。 同声相应，云从龙，风从虎，水流湿，火就燥，自然之数也。 苦恩第二十四 跂者不立，

chunks.original_text: 跂，进也。 谓贪权冒名，进取功荣，则不可久立身行道。 跨者不行， 自以为贵而跨之於人，众共蔽之，使不得行。 自见者不明， 凡人自见其形容以为好，自见其所行以为人道，殊不自知其形丑而操行之鄙。 自是者不彰， 自以为是而非人者，众共蔽之，使不彰显。 自伐者无功， 所为辄自伐取其功美，即自失有功於人。 自矜者不长。 好自矜大者，不可以久长。 其於道也，曰余食赘行。 赘，贵也。 使此自矜伐之人任治国之道，日赋敛，余禄食，为贪行。 物惑恶之， 此人在位，动欲伤害，故物无有不畏恶之。 故有道者不处。 言有道之人不居其国。 象元第二十五 有物混成，先天地生。 谓道也，道无形混沌，而生万物，乃在天地之前。 寂兮寥兮，独立而不改， 寂者，无音声。 寥者，空无形。 独立者，无匹双。 不改者，化有常。 周行而不殆， 道通行天地，无所不入，在阳不焦，托阴不腐，无不贯穿#6，而不危殆也。 可以为天下母。 道育养万物精气，如母之养子。 吾不知其名，字之曰道。 我不见道之形容，不知当何以名之。 见万物皆从道而生，故字之曰道。 强名之曰大。 不知其名，强名曰大。 高而无上，罗而无外，无不包容，故曰大。 大曰逝， 其为大，非若天，常在上； 非若地，常在下。 乃复逝去，无常处所。 逝日远， 言远者穷於无穷通，布气天地，无所不通也。 远曰反。 言其远不越绝，乃复反在人身。 故道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 道大者，包罗天地，无所不容。 天大者，无所不盖。 地大者，无所不载。 王大者，无所不制。 域中有四大，王居其一焉。 八极之内有四大，王居其一。 人法地， 人当法地，安静和柔也。 种之得五谷，掘之得甘泉，劳而不怨，有功而不置。 地法天， 天湛泊不动，施之不求报，生长万物，无所收取也。 天法道， 道法清浄不言，阴行精气，万物自然生长。 道法自然。 道性自然，无所法也。 重德第二十六 重为轻根， 人君不重则不尊，治身不重则失神。 草木花叶轻故零落也。 根重故能长存也。 静为躁君。 人君不静则失威，治身不静则身危。 龙静故能变化，虎躁故亏夭也。 是以圣人终日行，不离辎重。 辎，静也。 君子终日行道，不离其静重。 虽有荣观燕处，超然。 荣观谓宫阙。 燕处，后妃所居。 超然，远避而不处。 奈何万乘之主， 奈何者，疾其时伤痛之辞。 而以身轻於天下。 王者至尊，而於其身行轻躁乎。 疾时王奢恣轻淫，失其精也。 轻则失臣， 王者轻淫，则失其臣。 治身轻躁，则失其精也。 躁则失君。 王者行躁疾，则失其君位。 治身躁疾，则失其精神。 巧用第二十七 善行者无辙迹，
chunks.translated_text:
The **limping** are those who advance.
They who covet power and usurp fame,
who seek glory and gain—
cannot long stand firm in the Dao/Way.

The **straddling** do not walk.
They who exalt themselves above others,
the crowd conspires to obstruct them,
so they cannot proceed.

The **self-seeing** are blind.
Men who admire their own appearance as beautiful,
who deem their own actions the Dao/Way—
they fail to see their own ugliness,
their own vulgar conduct.

The **self-righteous** are not renowned.
They who insist they are right while others are wrong—
the crowd conspires to obscure them,
so they remain unillustrious.

The **self-praising** achieve nothing.
They who claim credit for their deeds,
in truth, lose the merit of true contribution.

The **self-glorifying** do not endure.
They who boast of their greatness
cannot long persist.
In the Dao/Way, they are called *"excessive food, superfluous actions."*
Superfluous—meaning *noble* in excess.
If such men govern the state,
they tax and extort,
hoarding surplus wealth—
their actions are gluttonous.
All things recoil in hatred.
When they hold office,
their every move brings harm,
so all fear and detest them.
Thus, the Dao/Way does not dwell there.

**Symbol of the Origin** (Chapter 25)
There exists a formless, mixed unity,
born before Heaven and Earth.
This is the Dao/Way—
shapeless, indistinct,
yet giving birth to all things,
existing before Heaven and Earth.

Silent and void,
it stands alone, unchanging.
Silent—without sound.
Void—without form.
Alone—without equal.
Unchanging—its transformations are eternal.

It moves in cycles without exhaustion,
permeating Heaven and Earth,
unscathed in the sun, uncorrupted in the shade,
penetrating all without peril.
It can be the mother of the world.
The Dao/Way nurtures the vital essence of all things,
as a mother nurtures her child.

I do not know its name—
so I call it the Dao/Way.
I do not see its form—
so I name it thus.
Seeing all things arise from the Dao/Way,
I name it the Dao/Way.
Forced to name it, I call it *Great*.
I do not know its name—
so I forcefully call it *Great*.

Lofty yet without summit,
encompassing yet without bounds—
thus it is *Great*.
Great is called *Fleeting*—
not like Heaven, always above,
not like Earth, always below.
Yet it departs, without fixed abode.

Fleeting is called *Distant*—
its distance extends to the boundless,
its qi permeating Heaven and Earth,
unobstructed in its passage.

Distant is called *Returning*—
its vastness does not sever,
but returns within the human realm.
Thus, the Dao/Way is Great,
Heaven is Great,
Earth is Great,
and the Sovereign is Great.

The Dao/Way is Great—
encompassing Heaven and Earth,
containing all without exclusion.
Heaven is Great—
covering all without omission.
Earth is Great—
bearing all without burden.
The Sovereign is Great—
commanding all without opposition.

Within the Four Extremes, there are Four Great Ones,
and the Sovereign is one of them.

Humans model themselves after Earth—
quiet, still, yielding, gentle—
planted, they yield grain;
dug, they yield sweet springs.
They labor without complaint,
perform deeds without expectation of reward.

Earth models itself after Heaven—
clear and undisturbed,
bestowing without seeking return,
nurturing all things without taking.

Heaven models itself after the Dao/Way—
the Dao/Way acts without speech,
its subtle qi flowing—
all things arise naturally.

The Dao/Way models itself after *Nature*.

**Chapter on Weighty Virtue** (Chapter 26)
Weight is the root of lightness—
a ruler who does not hold weight is not revered,
a man who does not hold weight loses his spirit.
Grass and trees, flowers and leaves are light—
thus they wither and fall.
Roots are heavy—
thus they endure.

Stillness is the master of agitation—
a ruler who is not still loses his authority,
a man who is not still endangers himself.
The dragon is still—
thus it transforms.
The tiger is agitated—
thus it perishes young.

Therefore, the Sage moves all day
yet never departs from his stillness.
His carriage is his stillness.
The gentleman walks the Dao/Way
yet never departs from his weighty composure.

Though he enjoys palaces and concubines,
he remains detached.
Palaces—meaning the royal halls.
Concubines—meaning the inner chambers.
Detached—meaning he avoids them.

How can the sovereign of ten thousand chariots
be so light in the world?
*How*—meaning he laments the pain of his time.
Yet he conducts himself lightly before all.

The sovereign’s excess and dissipation
drain his vital essence.
Lightness leads to losing his ministers,
agitation leads to losing his throne.
Agitation leads to losing his spirit.

**Chapter on Skillful Action** (Chapter 27)
The skilled practitioner leaves no trace.

chunks.original_text: 善行道者，求之於身，不下堂，不出门，故无辙迹。 善言无瑕谪， 善言谓择言而出之，则无瑕谪过於天下也。 善计不用筹策， 善以道计事者，则守一不移，所计不多，则不用筹策而知也。 善闭者无关键而不可开， 善以道闭情欲、守精神者，不如门户有关可得开也。 善结者无绳约而不可解。 善以道结事者，乃结其心，不如绳索可得解。 是以圣人常善救人， 圣人所以常教人忠孝，欲以救人性命。 故无弃人； 使贵贱各得其所也。 常善救物， 圣人所以顺四时，以救万物之伤残。 故无弃物。 圣人不贱石而贵玉，视之如一。 是谓袭明。 圣人善救人物，是谓袭明大道。 故善人者，不善人之师； 人之行善者，圣人则以为人师也。 不善人者，善人之资。 资，用也。 人行不善，犹教导使为善，得以给用。 不贵其师， 独无辅也。 不爱其资， 无所使也。 虽知大迷。 虽自以为智，言此人乃大迷惑也。 是谓要妙。 能通此道，是谓知微妙要道也。 反朴第二十八 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。 雄以喻尊，雌以喻卑。 人虽自知其尊显，当复守其卑微，去其雄之强梁，就其雌之柔和，如是则天下归之，如水之游深溪。 为天下溪，常德不离， 人能谦下如深溪，则德常在，不能离於己也。 复归於婴儿。 复当复志於婴兄，蠢然无所知也。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 白以喻昭昭，黑以喻默默。 人虽自知昭昭明达，当守之以默，如暗昧无所见，如是则可为天下法式，其德常在。 为天下式，常德不忒， 人能为天下法式，则德常在己，不复有差忒。 复归於无极。 德不差忒，则久寿长生，归身於无穷极#7。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 荣以喻尊贵，辱以喻污浊也。 知己之有荣贵，当守之以污浊，如是则天下归之，如水流入深谷也。 为天下谷，常德乃足， 足，止也。 人能为天下谷，德乃止於己。 复归於朴。 复当归身於质朴，不复为文饰。 朴散则为器， 万物之朴散，则为器用。 若道散，则为神明，为日月，分为五行。 圣人用之，则为官长， 圣人升用，则为百官之元长也。 故大制不割。 圣人用之，则以大道制御天下，无所伤害。 治身则以大道制御情欲，不害於精神。 无为第二十九 将欲取天下而为之， 将欲取#8天下，欲为天下主也。 而为之，欲以有为治民。 吾见其不得已。 我见其不得天道人心已明矣。 天道恶烦浊，人心恶多欲也。 天下神器，不可为也。 器，物也。 人乃天下之神物也。 神物好安静，不可以有为治。 为者败之， 以有为治之，则败其质性。 执者失之。 强执教之#9，则失精实，生於诈伪。 故物或行或随， 上所行之，下必随之。 或呴或吹， 呴，温也。 吹，寒也。 有所温，必有所寒。 或强惑羸， 有所强大，叉有所羸弱。 或载或隳。 载，安也。 集，危也。 有所安，必有所危。 明人君不可以有为治国治身。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 甚谓贪淫声色，奢谓服饰饮食，泰谓宫室台榭。 去此三者，处中和，行无为，则天下自化。 俭武第三十 以道佐人主者， 谓人主能以道自辅佐之矣。 不以兵强於天下， 以道自佐之主，不以兵革，顺天任德，敌人自服。 其事好还。 其举事好还自责，不怨於人。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 谓农事废，田不修。 大军之后，必有凶年。
chunks.translated_text:
The adept in the Dao/Way seeks it within himself,
never descending from his hall,
never stepping beyond his door—
thus leaving no trace.

The adept in speech has no flaws or blemishes,
for he selects his words with care,
and thus commits no errors before the world.

The adept in calculation needs no tally sticks,
for he adheres to the One without deviation,
and his schemes are few—
thus he knows without reckoning.

The adept in closure requires no locks or keys,
for he seals his passions and guards his spirit
more securely than doors with bolts.

The adept in binding needs no ropes or cords,
for he binds his heart—
more firmly than any tether.

Therefore, the Sage is always adept at saving people,
teaching them loyalty and filial piety
to rescue their very lives.
Thus, he abandons no one;
nobles and commoners each find their place.

He is always adept at saving things,
harmonizing with the Four Seasons
to rescue all creatures from harm.
Thus, he abandons nothing.

The Sage does not demean stone while honoring jade,
regarding them as one.
This is called *clinging to clarity*.

The Sage is adept at saving both people and things—
this is called *clinging to the Great Dao/Way*.

Thus, the virtuous become teachers for the unvirtuous,
for those who act rightly are made the Sage’s guides for others.

The unvirtuous become resources for the virtuous—
*resources*, meaning tools.
Even when people act wrongly,
they may still be guided toward virtue,
thus serving a purpose.

To dishonor one’s teacher
is to have no aid.
To disregard one’s resource
is to have nothing to employ.
Though one may claim wisdom,
such a person is deeply deluded.
This is called *the essential mystery*.

To grasp this Dao/Way is to know the subtle and essential.

**Chapter on Returning to Simplicity** (Chapter 28)
Knowing the masculine, he guards the feminine,
and becomes the valley of the world.
*The masculine*—meaning exalted status,
*the feminine*—meaning humility.
Though one knows his own exaltation,
he must guard his humility,
abandoning the masculine’s rigidity
and embracing the feminine’s gentleness—
thus the world flows toward him,
like water gathering in deep valleys.

To become the valley of the world,
his virtue remains unbroken.
He returns to the infant.
He must return his mind to the simplicity of the infant,
clumsy and unaware.

Knowing the bright, he guards the dark,
and becomes the model of the world.
*The bright*—meaning clarity,
*the dark*—meaning stillness.
Though one knows his own clarity,
he must guard it with silence,
as if in darkness, seeing nothing—
thus he becomes the standard for the world,
and his virtue remains unerring.

To become the model of the world,
his virtue never falters.
He returns to the boundless.

Knowing honor, he guards disgrace,
and becomes the valley of the world.
*Honor*—meaning nobility,
*disgrace*—meaning impurity.
Though one knows his own nobility,
he must guard it with humility,
as if stained—
thus the world flows toward him,
like water entering deep valleys.

To become the valley of the world,
his virtue is complete.
*Complete*—meaning settled.
He returns to simplicity.

When simplicity disperses, it becomes tools.
When the Dao disperses, it becomes spirit and clarity,
becoming the sun and moon,
dividing into the Five Phases.
The Sage employs it,
and it becomes officials and leaders.
Thus, great governance does not harm.

To govern the body, he employs the Dao
to regulate passions,
without harming the spirit.

**Chapter on Non-Action** (Chapter 29)
When one seeks to take the world by force,
I see it as inevitable failure.
The Dao/Way abhors complexity and filth,
human hearts abhor excess desire.
The world is a sacred vessel—
it cannot be seized.

*Vessel*—meaning essence.
Humans are the sacred essence of the world.
The sacred essence prefers tranquility
and cannot be governed by force.

Action ruins it,
grasping loses it.
Forcing instruction breeds deceit.

Thus, some advance, some retreat,
some are warmed, some are chilled,
some are strong, some are weak,
some are secure, some are endangered.

Therefore, the enlightened ruler cannot govern by force.
Thus, the Sage rejects excess,
rejects extravagance,
rejects extravagance.
*Excess*—meaning gluttony for sounds and colors,
*extravagance*—meaning attire, food, and dwellings,
*extravagance*—meaning palaces and pavilions.
Abandoning these three,
dwelling in moderation,
practicing non-action,
the world transforms itself.

**Chapter on Frugal Military Strategy** (Chapter 30)
To assist a ruler with the Dao/Way
is to have him govern without arms,
conquering the world without force.
His actions return to him naturally,
without blame.

Where his army passes,
thorns and brambles grow.
For agriculture is neglected,
fields left untended.
After great armies,
there are always years of famine.

How can the sovereign of ten thousand chariots
be so light in the world?
*How*—meaning he laments the pain of his time.
Yet he conducts himself lightly before all.

The sovereign’s excess and dissipation
drain his vital essence.
Lightness leads to losing his ministers,

**Chapter on Skillful Action** (Chapter 27)
The skilled practitioner leaves no trace.

The **Heaven** responds with the *killing qi*, and thus harms the five grains.
When the five grains are exhausted, it harms the people as well.

The virtuous act decisively, yet with restraint.
The virtuous wielders of arms—when they act decisively, they must dare to do so with restraint,
not seeking glory.
They do not dare to claim strength through conquest.
They do not seek the name of mighty armies through decisive yet arrogant actions.
Act decisively yet do not boast—when one acts decisively, they must remain humble,
not prideful in their strength.
Act decisively yet do not take credit—when one acts decisively, they must yield and not claim glory for themselves.
Act decisively yet do not be arrogant—arrogance is deception.
When one acts decisively, they must not deceive others with arrogance.
Act decisively only when unavoidable—when unavoidable, they must do so with utmost sincerity,
not through coercion or desperate compulsion.
Act decisively yet do not force—decisive action must not be seen as brute strength or impenetrable armor,
to oppress others.

When things flourish, they grow old—
when grass and trees reach their peak, they wither and fall,
when people reach their peak, they decline and age.
This means that strength cannot endure long.
This is called *not the Dao*—
those who wither and age sit and fail to follow the Dao.
Not the Dao leads to early ruin.
Those who do not follow the Dao die early.

**Chapter on Laying Down Arms** (Chapter 31)
Fine arms are not auspicious implements—
*auspicious* means *good*.
Arms are instruments that disturb the spirit,
cloud the harmonious *qi*—
they are not good implements,
and should not be adorned.

Some things are naturally repugnant—
when arms are used, harm is inevitable,
so all things naturally abhor them.
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon them.
Those who follow the Dao do not dwell in their lands.

The **gentleman** in peace values the left—
valuing the soft and yielding.
In war, they value the right—
valuing the strong and resolute.
This says that the Dao of arms is contrary to the Dao of the gentleman,
and what they cherish is different.

Arms are not auspicious implements,
nor are they the instruments of the gentleman—
not the implements the gentleman cherishes.
Only when unavoidable are they used—
when facing decline or calamity,
to protect the people,
not to plunder lands or covet wealth and treasures.
Victory yet without glory—
even if they achieve victory, they do not take pride in it.

But those who take pride in victory—
those who delight in killing—
are those who revel in slaughtering others.
Those who excel in achieving victory
are those who are said to take joy in killing.

He who takes joy in killing
cannot fulfill his ambitions in the world.
For a ruler who takes joy in killing,
this is why he cannot make his will prevail in the world.

A sovereign who delights in killing
must necessarily control the lives of his people,
and recklessly execute and slaughter them.
Thus, auspicious matters are honored on the left—
the left, the place of life.
Ominous matters are honored on the right—
the Dao of the dark governs death.
The subordinate general stands on the left—
the subordinate general is lowly and occupies the position of the bright.
The supreme general stands on the right—
the supreme general is exalted and occupies the rightful position,
for he governs death.
This is said in the context of funeral rites.
The supreme general resides on the right,
overseeing funeral rites.
Funeral rites are honored on the right,
for the dead are held in darkness.
When the number of slain is great,
they mourn with sorrow and tears.
When one’s own virtue is thin,
he cannot transform the people through the Dao,
and thus harms the innocent.
When victorious in battle,
he treats it as a funeral rite.
In ancient times, when victorious in battle,
the general would occupy the position of the funeral master,
dressed in plain white garments and weeping.
The wise gentleman values virtue over arms,
and when arms are unavoidable,
he punishes what is inauspicious,
yet his heart does not rejoice in it,
comparing it to a funeral.
Knowing that future generations will not cease from arms,
he mourns and grieves deeply.

**Chapter Thirty-Two: The Virtue of the Dao**
The Dao is constant and nameless.
The Dao can be dark and bright,
can relax and expand,
can preserve and perish—
thus it has no constant name.
Though simple and unadorned,
the Dao is vast, and the world dare not enslave it.
The Dao is simple yet subtle and formless,
and the world dare not enslave those who embody it.
If lords and kings can uphold it,
all things will come to serve of their own accord.
If lords and kings can uphold the Dao,
all things will naturally submit and follow in virtue’s transformation.
When Heaven and Earth unite,
sweet dew descends—
when the actions of lords and kings align with Heaven and Earth,
Heaven bestows sweet dew and auspicious blessings.
The people need no command,
yet all things are balanced.
When Heaven’s sweet dew and auspicious blessings descend,
no thing needs teaching or ordering,
yet all things naturally adjust in harmony.
The Dao first gives rise to names—
the Dao, which is the Way,
gives rise to named things, the myriad beings.
The Dao is nameless, yet it governs what is named;
formless, yet it governs what is formed.
Once names exist,
all named things have desires and emotions,
rebelling against the Dao and departing from virtue,
thus their bodies are destroyed and dishonored.
Heaven will also come to know of it.
If a person can follow the Dao and cultivate virtue,
Heaven will also come to know of it.
Knowing of it,
this is why there is no peril.
When Heaven knows of it,
its divine clarity aids and protects,
and no longer is there danger or peril.
The Dao in the world is like streams and valleys to the rivers and seas.

The Dao is vast and boundless,
like something submerged or floating,
like something present yet absent,
seen yet not seen,
spoken yet hard to distinguish.

Its influence can be turned left or right.
The Dao can be applied left or right,
adapting to all circumstances.

All things depend upon it to arise,
*[shì]*, meaning they await the Dao to give birth.
Yet the Dao does not refuse or decline.
The Dao does not reject and cease.

Its work accomplished, it does not claim ownership.
Though the Dao possesses virtue,
it does not name itself as such.

It nurtures all things yet does not lord over them.
Though the Dao cherishes and sustains all things,
it does not take as a ruler does.

Constantly without desire,
it may be called small.
The Dao conceals its traces and hides its name,
calmly acting without doing,
seeming faint and insignificant.

Yet all things return to it without being ruled,
all things return to the Dao to receive its *qi*,
yet the Dao does not prohibit like a ruler.

Thus it may be called great.
All things come and go freely,
each acting according to its own nature,
so it may be called the greatest.

Therefore, the sage never claims greatness,
the sage follows the Dao,
conceals virtue and hides its name,
not seeking to fill itself with greatness.

Thus it can achieve true greatness.
The sage leads by embodying the Dao,
acting without words yet transforming,
all matters refined and ordered,
thus it can achieve true greatness.

**Chapter 35: Virtue of Benevolence**
Hold the great symbol,
and the world will follow.
*[zhí]*, meaning to uphold;
*[xiàng]*, meaning the Dao.
When the sage upholds the great Dao,
the world’s people turn their hearts and follow.

Order oneself,
and Heaven grants divine clarity,
moving toward you.
When the sage orders its own being,
Heaven sends its divine light,
coming and going with you.

Coming yet not harming,
peace and tranquility ensue.
All things follow yet are not injured,
so the state becomes secure and attains great peace.

Ordering oneself without harming divine clarity,
the body remains at ease and attains great longevity.
Delight and allure,
passing travelers stop.

*[ĕr]*, meaning beauty;
*[guòkè]*, meaning singularity.
When a person finds beauty in the Dao,
it abides in singularity.
Singularity means to depart from excess and embrace emptiness,
to dwell lightly as a passing traveler.

When the Dao emerges from the mouth,
it is faint and without taste.
The Dao enters and exits through the mouth in faintness,
not like the five flavors—
sour, salty, sweet, bitter, and pungent.

Viewing it, one cannot see it fully.
*[zú]*, meaning attainment.
The Dao is formless,
not like the five colors—
green, yellow, red, white, and black,
which can be fully attained by sight.

Listening to it, one cannot hear it fully.
The Dao is not like the five tones—
*gōng, shāng, jiǎo, zhǐ, yǔ*,

Using it, it cannot be exhausted.
*[jì]*, meaning completion;
meaning that when the Dao is used to govern the state,
the state becomes wealthy and its people flourish,
when used to order oneself,
longevity extends—
there is no time of exhaustion.

First, expand it fully,
so that its extravagance and excess may reach their height.
When you wish to weaken it,
you must first make it strong;
first strengthen it,
so that it may meet with misfortune and harm.

When you wish to discard it,
you must first elevate it;
elevating it first,
so that its arrogance and excess may reach peril.
When you wish to take it away,
you must first give it.
Giving it first,
so that its prideful desires may be fully indulged.

This is called *Subtle Clarity*.

These four matters—
their Dao is subtle,
yet their effects are clear.

The soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.
The soft and weak endure long,
while the hard and strong perish first.

Fish do not escape from the depths,
but when fish escape from the depths,
it means they have left the hard for the soft,
and cannot be recaptured.

The state’s sharpest tools
should not be shown to the people.
Sharp tools refer to *power*.
Those who wield power in governing the state
should not reveal it to their attending ministers.
Those who practice the Dao of self-cultivation
should not reveal it to those unworthy.

**Chapter 37: Governing with Dao**

The Dao acts without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
The Dao abides in non-action as its constant.
If lords and kings can uphold it,
all things will transform of their own accord.
This means that if lords and kings uphold the Dao,
all things will spontaneously manifest their effects for them.

When transformation begins to stir,
I will restrain it with the uncarved simplicity of the Nameless.
*I* refers to the self.
The *Nameless* refers to the Dao.
When all things manifest their effects for them,
yet still desire to act with artifice and deceit,
lords and kings must restrain them with virtue and Dao.

The uncarved simplicity of the Nameless
will then also not desire to act,
and by not desiring, it remains tranquil.
This means that when lords and kings restrain with virtue and Dao,
the people will also not desire to act,
so they must be transformed through the tranquil Way.

Then the world will spontaneously align itself.
Those who can do this—
the world will spontaneously align and settle.

chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter 38: On Virtue**

The highest virtue is non-virtue.
By "highest virtue," it refers to the sovereigns of the primordial age, whose virtue was supreme and nameless.
To say "non-virtue" means they did not govern through virtue but followed nature’s course, nurturing life and destiny without visible intervention.
Thus, they *had* virtue—
for their virtue harmonized with Heaven and Earth, blending with the flowing *qi*, allowing the people to thrive.

The lower virtue is not lost virtue.
By "lower virtue," it refers to sovereigns with titles and posthumous names, whose virtue fell short of the highest.
To say "not lost virtue" means their virtue was visible, their deeds praiseworthy.
Thus, they *lack* virtue—
because they bore names and titles.

The highest virtue does nothing.
This means adhering to the Dao’s tranquil stillness, making no alterations.
Yet it does nothing—
meaning it does not rely on names or titles.

The lower virtue acts.
This means issuing edicts and administering governance.
Yet it does so—
meaning it uses these deeds to claim titles for itself.

The highest benevolence acts.
By "highest benevolence," it refers to sovereigns who practice benevolence, whose virtue is unmatched.
To say "acts" means they enact benevolent kindness.
Yet they do nothing—
for when their deeds are complete, they do not cling to them.

The highest righteousness acts.
This refers to righteousness in punishing harm.
Yet it does so—
meaning they act for personal gain, killing to assert power, taxing the people to sustain themselves.

The highest ritual acts.
By "highest ritual," it refers to sovereigns whose rituals are unmatched.
To say "acts" means they establish ritual institutions and ceremonial order.
Yet none respond—
for ritual flourishes in form while substance decays, its excesses and deceits multiplying, every action straying from the Dao, making response impossible.
Thus, they raise their arms and force compliance—
meaning the burdensome rituals, unanswered, provoke resentment and strife, so they compel obedience by force.

Hence, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises;
when virtue is lost, benevolence appears;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness is enforced;
when righteousness is lost, ritual is imposed.
For ritual is the thinnest layer of loyalty and sincerity—
meaning ritual abandons the root to adorn the branches, so uprightness dwindles while deceit proliferates.

Prescience is the Dao’s superficial bloom, the beginning of folly.
To speak without knowing is prescience.
This is when people lose the Dao in truth but grasp its superficiality—
the first spark of folly and darkness among men.

Thus, the true sage abides in substance,
by "true sage," meaning the sovereign who embodies the Dao.
To "abide in substance" means to dwell in sincerity and simplicity.
They do not abide in superficiality—
meaning they do not indulge in worldly turmoil and excess.
They reside in truth—
meaning they uphold loyalty and sincerity.
They do not reside in superficiality—
meaning they do not prize empty words.
Thus, they discard the latter and embrace the former.

**Chapter 39: The Law of the One**

Those of old who attained the One—
"of old" refers to the past; "the One" is non-action, the child of the Dao.
Heaven attains the One and becomes clear,
Earth attains the One and becomes tranquil—
meaning Heaven, through the One, manifests its luminous forms;
Earth, through the One, remains steadfast and unshaken.

The spirit attains the One and becomes numinous—
meaning the spirit, through the One, transforms without effort.
The valleys attain the One and become full—
meaning the valleys, through the One, remain abundant without depletion.
All things attain the One and thrive—
meaning all things depend on the Dao for their existence.
The lords and kings attain the One to rectify the world—
meaning they, through the One, bring order to the realm.

Yet if they overreach—
"overreach" is a warning—concerning the following six dangers:
Heaven, without clarity, would fear rupture—
meaning Heaven must balance yin and yang, alternating day and night; if it clings only to stillness, it risks fracturing and losing its heavenly nature.

Earth, without tranquility, would fear eruption—
meaning Earth must embrace elevation and depression, hardness and softness, the five phases; if it clings only to stillness, it risks upheaval and losing its earthly nature.

The spirit, without numinosity, would fear exhaustion—
meaning the spirit must cycle through kingship, decline, and decay; if it clings only to vitality, it risks stagnation and losing its divine essence.

The valleys, without fullness, would fear depletion—
meaning the valleys must cycle through abundance and scarcity; if they cling only to fullness, they risk drying up and losing their nourishing nature.

All things, without generation, would fear annihilation—
meaning all things must follow the natural cycles of birth and death; if they cling only to life, they risk extinction and losing their true form.

The lords and kings, without humility, would fear downfall—
meaning they must humble themselves, seek worthy counsel; if they cling only to exaltation, they risk ruin and losing their rule.

Thus, nobility must root itself in humility—
meaning if one seeks true elevation, they must ground it in lowliness.
Like Yu and Shi tilling the fields, Shun molding by the river, the Duke of Zhou dwelling in humble halls—
highness must be built upon lowliness.
For if the foundation is not firm, the structure will inevitably collapse.

Hence, lords and kings call themselves "lonely and few, unworthy of the harvest"—
"lonely and few" signifies solitude; "unworthy of the harvest" signifies they cannot be the hub around which all else revolves.
Is this not the essence of rooting in humility?
They speak thus to enlighten others.
Alas, it is but deceitful speech.

chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, gathering countless chariot parts yields no chariot—
*致* (zhi) here means "to gather."
It speaks of how people gather chariot parts—
for the spokes, for the wheels, for the hub, for the axle—
yet none can be called a "chariot" until they are assembled.
This illustrates how lords and kings, by not claiming exalted titles,
can thereby achieve true nobility.

They do not wish to be polished like jade,
nor stark like stone.
*碌碌* (luoluo) signifies scarcity;
*落落* (luoluo) signifies abundance.
Jade is scarce, hence its value;
stone is plentiful, hence its lowliness.
It speaks of how people should not seek to be prized like jade,
nor despised like stone,
but rather dwell in moderation.

**Dao/Way’s Movement (反者道之动)**
*反* (fan) here means "root" or "origin."
The root is what makes the Dao/Way move—
movement generates all things;
to go against it is to perish.
The Dao/Way’s use is in weakness.

The soft and yielding are what the Dao/Way habitually employs,
and thus they endure.
All things under heaven are born from what is present—
things arise from the forms and positions of heaven and earth,
so it is said they are born from what is present.
Yet what is present is born from what is absent.

Heaven and earth, divine and luminous,
the *蜎* (ying) flying, the *蠕* (ru) crawling—
all arise from the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way is formless, hence it is said they are born from what is absent.

This speaks of how the root surpasses the flourish,
the weak surpass the strong,
and humility surpasses fullness.

**Hearing the Dao/Way (同异第四十一)**
The superior person hears the Dao/Way
and strives diligently to practice it.
The middle person hears the Dao/Way
and clings to it, yet falters—
they strive to cultivate themselves for long life,
to govern their state for lasting peace,
and take pleasure in its teachings.
But when they encounter wealth, desire, honor, or glory,
they are bewildered by their passions
and thus lose it again.
The inferior person hears the Dao/Way
and laughs at it.
The inferior are greedy, cruel, and filled with desires;
they see the Dao/Way’s softness and call it fearsome.
They see its plainness and call it vulgar.
Thus, they laugh at it.

If one does not laugh at it,
it is not worthy to be called the Dao/Way.
If the Dao/Way is not laughed at by the inferior,
it is not yet fully the Dao/Way.
Hence, I set forth these sayings:

The bright Dao/Way seems dim,
the advancing Dao/Way seems to retreat,
the smooth Dao/Way seems crooked.
The superior in virtue seems like a deep valley,
the great purity seems like a stain,
the vast virtue seems insufficient,
the established virtue seems hollow.
The truthful seem false,
the upright seem misaligned,
the great instrument takes long to mature,
the great sound is rare in voice,
the great image is formless,
the Dao/Way is hidden, nameless.

Only the Dao/Way
is good at lending and completing.
*成* (cheng) here means "to fulfill."
It speaks of how the Dao/Way is good at bestowing upon people
their vital *qi* and bringing them to completion.

**The Transformations of the Dao/Way (道化第四十二)**
The Dao/Way first generates *一* (yi),
the primal unity.
*一* (yi) generates *二* (er),
the duality of yin and yang.
*二* (er) generates *三* (san),
the three *qi* of harmony, clarity, and turbidity,
which divide into heaven, earth, and humanity.
*三* (san) generates all things.
Heaven and earth, humanity together generate all things.

Heaven bestows, earth transforms,
and humanity nurtures them.
All things bear yin and embrace yang,
turning toward the sun as they revolve.
The *冲气* (chongqi) of harmony pervades them all—
within all things lies the primal *qi*,
and when harmonized and softened,
it is like marrow in bones,
or the void within grasses and trees.
The *qi* of harmony flows silently,
and thus they attain longevity.

What people detest
is the "lonely and few, unworthy of the harvest,"
yet lords and kings take it as their name.
"Lonely and few, unworthy of the harvest"
is an ill-omened title,
yet lords and kings adopt it,
dwelling in humility,
embodying emptiness, harmony, and softness.
Thus, some things are diminished yet gain,
some are drawn yet cannot be held,
some are pushed yet return.
Some gain yet are diminished.

He who raises himself too high invites collapse,
he who covets wealth and honor invites calamity.
What people are taught
is to abandon the weak for the strong,
to abandon the soft for the hard.
I also teach this—
I teach people to abandon the strong for the weak,
to abandon the hard for the soft.

The rigid and forceful
do not meet a natural death.
The rigid and forceful
do not believe in the mysterious and profound,
they betray morality,
do not follow the teachings,
but rely on power and strength.
It is said they do not meet a natural death—
they are cut off by heaven,
slain by weapons,
executed by law,
and do not die by the full span of their years.
I shall take them as my first lesson.

**The Dao/Way’s Partial Use (偏用第四十三)**
The utmost softness under heaven
overcomes the utmost hardness under heaven.
The utmost softness is water,
the utmost hardness is metal and stone.
Water can penetrate hardness,
enter rigidity—
nothing it cannot pass through.
There is nothing it cannot enter without gap.

It is said there is nothing it cannot enter—
this is the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way has no form or substance,
and thus can move freely without obstruction,
penetrating the divine and luminous,
benefiting all living things.
Thus, I know the benefits of *无为* (wuwei).

I see how the Dao/Way’s *wuwei*
yet all things transform and complete themselves—
thus I know the benefits of *wuwei* for humanity.

chunks.original_text: 不言之教， 法道不言#11，师之於身。 无为之益， 法道无为，治身则有益於精神，治国则有益於万民，不劳烦也。 天下希及之。 天下，人主也。 希能有及道之无为。 无为之治，治身治国也。 立戒第四十四 名与身孰亲？ 名遂身必退也。 身与货孰多？ 财多则害身也。 得与亡孰病？ 好於利则病於行也。 甚爱必大费， 甚爱色者，费精神也； 甚爱财者，遇祸患也。 所爱者少，所亡者多，故言大费者也。 多藏必厚亡。 生多藏於府库，死多藏於丘墓。 生有攻劫之忧，死有掘发之息。 知足不辱， 知足之人，绝利去欲，不辱於身。 知止不殆， 知可止则须止，乃财利不累於身心，声色不乱於耳目，则终身不危殆。 可以长久。 人能知於止足，则福禄在於己。 治身者神不劳，治国者民不扰，故能长久。 洪德第四十五 大成若缺， 谓道德大成之君。 若缺者，灭名藏誉，如毁缺不备。 其用不弊； 其用心如此，则无弊尽之时。 大盈若冲， 谓道德大盈满之君。 如冲者，贵不敢骄，富不敢奢。 其用不穷。 其用心如此，则无穷尽时。 大直若屈， 大直谓#12修道法度正直如一也。 如屈者，不与俗人争，如可#13屈折也。 大巧若拙， 大巧谓多才衍也。 如拙者，亦不敢见其能。 大辩若讷。 大辩者，智无疑。 如讷者，口无辞。 躁胜寒， 胜，极也。

**The Dao/Way’s Silent Instruction (不言之教)**
By law of the Dao/Way, that which is not spoken#11,
the teacher applies it to oneself.

The benefits of *wuwei* are such:
by law of the Dao/Way’s *wuwei*,
governing the body brings benefit to **spirit/qi**,
governing the state brings benefit to all the people—
without toil or vexation.

Few under heaven can attain this.

The world, its ruler is humanity.
If few can attain the Dao/Way’s *wuwei*,
then *wuwei* governance is both of body and state.

**Establishing Precepts (立戒第四十四)**
Which is more dear to you, name or body?
If name follows body, it must decline.
Which is more abundant, body or wealth?
If wealth is abundant, it harms the body.
Which is more painful, gain or loss?
If one clings to profit, one’s actions will falter.

Excessive love brings great cost.
Excessive love of beauty wastes **spirit/qi**,
excessive love of wealth invites calamity.
What is loved is little, what is lost is much—
thus it is said that great cost arises.
Excessive hoarding brings great loss.
The living hoard in treasuries,
the dead hoard in tombs.
The living face fears of plunder and assault,
the dead face fears of desecration and neglect.

Knowing contentment brings no disgrace,
the contented one cuts off profit and desire—
no disgrace befalls the body.

Knowing restraint brings no peril,
he who knows when to stop must stop,
then wealth and profit do not weigh upon the body and mind,
sensual pleasures do not disturb the ears and eyes—
thus he remains throughout life unthreatened,
able to endure.

If humanity can know to stop at contentment,
then fortune and blessings are within themselves.
He who governs his body does not weary **spirit/qi**,
he who governs his state does not trouble the people—
thus he can endure long.

**Abundant Virtue/Power (洪德第四十五)**
Great virtue/power, though complete, seems deficient.
This refers to a sovereign of great Dao/virtue/power:
though complete, he hides his name and renown,
as if destroyed or incomplete.
His governance knows no exhaustion—
when his heart is thus, there is no time when virtue/power is spent.

Great fullness seems empty.
This refers to a sovereign of great Dao/virtue/power, overflowing with abundance:
though full, he does not dare to be arrogant in his high rank,
though rich, he does not dare to be extravagant.
His governance knows no depletion—
when his heart is thus, there is no time when virtue/power is exhausted.

Great rectitude seems bent.
Great rectitude refers to one who follows the Dao/Way’s laws and precepts with perfect uprightness.
Though bent, he does not contend with the common folk,
as if he could be bent and folded.

Great cleverness seems clumsy.
Great cleverness refers to one with many talents and skills.
Though clumsy, he does not dare to show his abilities.

Great eloquence seems inarticulate.
Great eloquence refers to one whose wisdom is unquestionable.
Though inarticulate, his speech is without words.

Excessive vigor overcomes coldness—
*vigor*, here, means extreme.

chunks.original_text: 春夏，阳气躁疾於上，万物盛大。 极则寒，寒则零落散亡也，言人不当刚躁也。 静胜热， 秋冬，万物静於黄泉之下。 极则热，热者生之源也。 清静以为天下正。 能清能静，则为天下之长，持正则无终已时也。 俭欲第四十六 天下有道， 谓人主有道。 却走马以粪； 粪者，粪田也。 兵甲不用，却走马以治农田也。 治身者却阳精，以粪其身也。 天下无道， 谓人主无道也。 戎马生於郊。 战伐不止，戎马生於郊境之上，久不还。 罪莫大於可欲， 好色淫欲。 祸莫大於不知足， 富贵不能自知禁止。 咎莫大於欲得。 欲得人物利且贪也。 故知足之足， 守真根也。 常足矣。 谓无有欲心。 鉴远第四十七 不出户，以知天下； 圣人不出户以知天下者，以己身知人身，以己家知人家，所以见天下也。 不窥牖，见天道。 天道与人道同，天人相通，精气相贯。 人君清静，天气自正； 人君多欲，天气烦浊。 吉凶利害，皆由於己者也。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 谓去其家观人家，去其身观人身，所观益远，所见益少。 是以圣人不行而知， 圣人不上天，不入渊，能知天下者，以心知之也。 不见而名， 上好道，下好德； 上好武，下好力。 圣人原小而知大，察内而知外也。 不为而成。 上好无为，则下无事，家给人足，万物自化也。 忘知第四十八 为学日益， 学谓政教礼乐之学也#14。 日益者，情欲文饰日以益多。 为道日损。 道谓自然之道。 日损者，情欲文饰日以销损。 损之又损， 损之，损情欲也。 又损之者，所以渐去之也。 以至於无为， 当恬淡如婴儿，无所造为。 无为而无不为。 情欲断绝，德与道合，则无所不施，无所不为也。 取天下常以无事， 取，治也。 治天下当以无事，不当劳烦也。 及其有事，不可以取天下。 及其好有事，则政教烦，民不安，故不足以治天下。 任德第四十九 圣人无常心， 圣人重改更，贵因循，若似无心也。 以百姓心为心。 百姓心之所便，因而从之。 善者吾善之， 百姓为善，圣人因而善之。 不善者吾亦善之， 百姓虽有不善者，圣人化之使善也。 德善。 百姓德化，圣人为善。 信者吾信之， 百姓为信，圣人因而信之。 不信者吾亦信之， 百姓为不信，圣人化之使信也。 德信。 百姓德化，圣人为信。 圣人在天下怵怵， 圣人在天下怵怵，常恐惧富贵，不敢骄奢。 为天下浑其心。 言圣人为天下百姓浑浊其心，若愚暗不通。 百姓皆注其耳目， 注，用也。 百姓皆用其耳目为圣人视聪也。 圣人皆孩之。 圣人爱念百姓如婴孩赤子，长养之而不责望其报。 贵生第五十 出生入死，
chunks.translated_text:
Spring and summer, the **yang qi** is restless and swift above,
all things flourish and grow vast.
When it reaches its extreme, coldness follows—
coldness brings withering and scattering to ruin,
a warning that one must not be overly rigid and restless.

**Calmness overcomes heat**—
in autumn and winter, all things rest beneath the Yellow Springs.
When it reaches its extreme, heat arises—
heat is the source of life’s vitality.
**Clarity and stillness** establish the **Dao/Way** as the standard for the world.
If one can be clear and still,
then one becomes the leader of the world,
and holding to this standard knows no end.

**Frugality** (the forty-sixth) —
When the ruler follows the **Dao/Way**,
he uses **walking horses** to fertilize the fields;
*fertilize*, here, means **cultivating the soil**.
He does not employ arms,
but uses **walking horses** to tend the farmlands.
One who governs himself **restrains his yang essence**,
using it to **fertilize his own body**.

When the ruler does not follow the **Dao/Way**,
**walking horses** breed in the suburbs.
Warfare never ceases,
and **walking horses** multiply in the borderlands,
never returning home.
No crime is greater than **excessive desire**,
for lustful indulgence.
No calamity is greater than **not knowing contentment**,
for the rich and noble cannot restrain themselves.
No fault is greater than **greed for gain**,
desiring wealth, influence, and profit.
Thus, **contentment’s root is contentment itself**—
**true contentment** lies in guarding the **original essence**.
Always content,
meaning **without desire at all**.

**Reflecting from afar** (the forty-seventh) —
Without leaving his door, he knows the world;
the sage does not need to leave his door to know the world,
for he understands it by knowing the **human body** through his own,
and **human families** through his own.
Thus he perceives the world.
Without peering through windows, he beholds **Heaven’s Dao/Way**.
**Heaven’s Dao/Way** and **human Dao/Way** are alike—
**Heaven** and **humanity** are in harmony,
their **refined qi** interpenetrating.
When the ruler is clear and still,
**Heaven’s qi** naturally aligns.
When the ruler is excessive in desire,
**Heaven’s qi** becomes troubled and murky.
**Fortune, misfortune, benefit, and harm** all arise from within.
The farther he goes,
the less he knows.
Meaning: when he leaves his own home to observe others,
or his own body to observe others’,
the more distant his gaze,
the less he truly sees.
Thus the sage knows without traveling—
the sage neither ascends to **Heaven** nor descends into the depths,
yet knows the world through his **heart**.
He names without seeing—
when the ruler above values **Dao/Way**, those below value **virtue/power**;
when the ruler above values **martial might**, those below value **strength**.
The sage discerns the small to grasp the great,
and examines the inner to comprehend the outer.

**Achievement through non-action** —
The sage acts without striving.
When the ruler above favors **non-action** (*wuwei*),
those below have no need for exertion,
families are well-provided, and people are content—
all things transform naturally.

**Forgetting knowledge** (the forty-eighth) —
To study daily is to increase;
*study*, here, refers to **governance, teaching, rituals, and music**.
To **increase daily** means **refining emotions, desires, and artificial adornments** grow ever more plentiful.
To follow the **Dao/Way** daily is to diminish.
The **Dao/Way** refers to **natural spontaneity**.
To **diminish daily** means **refining emotions, desires, and artificial adornments** are gradually worn away.
**Diminish again and again**—
*diminish*, here, means **eradicating desires**.
**Again and again** refers to **gradually removing them**.
Until he reaches **non-action**—
when he is **serene and simple**, like an infant,
**creating nothing artificially**.
**Non-action yet nothing remains undone**—
when desires are severed and **virtue/power** aligns with the **Dao/Way**,
he accomplishes all without effort.
To **govern the world**, one must act with **non-interference**—
*govern*, here, means **to rule**.
Ruling the world should be done with **non-interference**,
not with labor and disturbance.
Once **interference** arises,
one cannot rule the world.
When one **loves interference**,
governance grows troubled,
and the people are restless—
thus it is insufficient for ruling the world.

**Entrusting to virtue** (the forty-ninth) —
The sage has no fixed heart,
meaning the sage **values transformation and adaptation**,
**follows natural progression**,
as if **without a settled intention**.
He takes the **hundred folk’s heart** as his own.
Whatever benefits the **hundred folk**,
he follows accordingly.
If they are **good**, I **nurture their goodness**—
when the **hundred folk** act well,
the sage **reinforces their virtue**.
If they are **not good**, I **also nurture their goodness**—
though the **hundred folk** may have those who are **not good**,
the sage **transforms them** until they become good.
**Virtue is thus cultivated**.
When the **hundred folk’s virtue** is transformed,
the sage **acts with goodness**.

If they are **faithful**, I **affirm their faithfulness**—
when the **hundred folk** act faithfully,
the sage **reinforces their trustworthiness**.
If they are **not faithful**, I **also affirm their faithfulness**—
though the **hundred folk** may have those who are **not faithful**,
the sage **transforms them** until they become faithful.
**Virtue is thus trustworthy**.
When the **hundred folk’s virtue** is transformed,
the sage **acts with trust**.

The sage in the world is **solemn and cautious**—
the sage in the world is **solemn and cautious**,
always fearing **wealth and nobility**,
never daring to be **arrogant or extravagant**.
He **muddles the world’s heart**—
meaning the sage **clouds the hearts of the hundred folk**,
as if they were **simple and unknowing**.
The **hundred folk** all **fix their ears and eyes** upon him—
*fix*, here, means **to rely on**.
The **hundred folk** all **rely on his ears and eyes** as their **vision and hearing**.
The sage **treats them like infants**—
the sage **cherishes and nurtures the hundred folk** as if they were **babies or young children**,
**cultivating them without expectation of reward**.

chunks.original_text: 出生，谓情欲出於五内，魂定魄静，故生也。 入死，谓情欲入胸臆，精神劳惑，故死也。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三， 言生死之类各十有三，谓九窍四关也。 其生也，目不妄视，耳不妄听，鼻不妄香臭，口不妄言味，手不妄持，足不妄行，精不妄施。 其死反是。 人之生，动之死地十有三。 人之求生，动作反之，十有三死地也。 夫何故？ 问何故动之死地也。 以其生生之厚也。 所以动之死地也，以其求生太厚，违道忤天，妄行於己。 盖闻善摄生者， 摄，养也。 陆行不遇兕虎， 自然远避，害不干也。 入军不被甲兵， 不好战以杀人。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 养生之人，虎兕无由伤，兵刃无从加也。 夫何故？ 问虎兕兵甲何故不害之。 以其无死地。 以其不犯十三之死地。 言神明营护之，兵兕不敢害。 养德第五十一 道生之，
chunks.translated_text:
**Birth** refers to when **emotions and desires arise from the five viscera**—
when the **hun** is steadfast and the **po** is tranquil, thus **life** emerges.

**Death** refers to when **emotions and desires sink into the chest and abdomen**—
when **spirit and essence** grow weary and confused, thus **death** comes.

There are **thirteen paths to life**,
and **thirteen paths to death**—
meaning the **kinds of birth and death** each number thirteen,
namely the **nine orifices and four gates**.

In **life**, the eyes do not gaze wantonly,
the ears do not listen indiscriminately,
the nose does not indulge in foul or fragrant odors,
the mouth does not speak or taste recklessly,
the hands do not grasp at will,
the feet do not move arbitrarily,
and the **essence** is not wasted.

In **death**, the opposite holds true.

**Thirteen actions** lead a person to **death’s domain**—
but when one **seeks life**, those same actions, reversed, become **thirteen paths to death**.

Why is this?
*—Why do these actions lead to death’s domain?*
Because **life’s excess** is too great.

The reason these actions lead to death’s domain
is that **seeking life is too extreme**—
it **contradicts the Dao** and **defies Heaven**,
acting recklessly against oneself.

Now, those who **master life-nurturing**—

—**walk on land** and **avoid rhinoceros and tigers**,
naturally keeping far from harm.

They **enter battle** without armor or weapons,
*—not favoring war or killing.*
The rhinoceros has no place to strike with its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claws,
and weapons no place to strike with their blades.

Those who **nurture life**—
tigers and rhinoceros find no way to harm them,
and blades have no means to strike.

Why is this?
*—Why do tigers, rhinoceros, and weapons not harm them?*
Because they **avoid death’s domain**—
because they **do not violate the thirteen paths to death**.
*—Meaning the **spirit and clarity** protect them,
and tigers, rhinoceros, and weapons dare not harm.*

chunks.original_text: 道生万物。 德畜之， 德，一也。 一主#15布气，而畜养。 物形之， 一为万物设形象也。 势成之。 一为万物作寒暑之势以成之。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道德所为，莫不尽惊动而尊敬。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之命，而常自然。 道一不命召万物，而常自然应之如影响。 故道生之，德畜之，长之育之，成之熟之，养之覆之。 道生於万物，非但生而已，乃复长养、成熟#16、覆育，全其性命。 人君治国治身，亦当如是也。 生而不有， 道生万物，不有所取以为利用。 为而不恃， 道所施为，不恃望其报也。 长而不宰， 道长养万物，不宰害以为利。 是谓玄德。 道之所行恩德，玄暗不可得见。 归元第五十二 天下有始， 始者，道也。 以为天下母。 道为天下万物之母也。 既知其母，复知其子； 子，一也。 既知道已，当复知一。 既知其子，复守其母， 既知其一，当复守道，反无为也。 没身不殆。 不危殆也。 塞其兑， 兑，目也。 目不妄视。 闭其门， 门，口也。 使口不妄言。 终身不勤。 人当塞目不妄视，闭口不妄言，则身不勤苦。 开其兑， 开其目，视情欲。 济其事， 济，益也。 益情欲之事。 终身不救。 祸乱成也。 见小曰明， 萌牙未动，祸乱未见为小，昭然独见为明。 守柔曰强。 守柔弱曰以强大也。 用其光， 用其目光於外，视时世之利害也。 复归其明。 言复反其光明於内，无使精神泄也。 无遗身殃， 内视全神，不为漏失。 是谓习常。 人能行此，是谓习修常道。 益证第五十三 使我介然有知，行於大道。 介，大也。 老子疾时王不行大道，故设言：使我介然有知於政事，我则行於大道，躬行无为之化也。 唯施是畏。 唯，独也。 独畏有所施为失道意。 欲赏善恐#17伪善生，欲信#18忠恐诈忠起也。 大道甚夷， 夷，平易也。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** gives birth to myriad things.
**Virtue** nurtures them—**virtue** is singular.
The singular **Dao** distributes **qi** to all,
and **virtue** nourishes and sustains them.
It shapes their forms—
the singular **Dao** establishes shapes and likenesses for all things.
It forms their conditions—
the singular **Dao** creates the forces of cold and heat to bring them to fulfillment.
Thus, all things without fail revere the **Dao** and hold **virtue** in high esteem.
Whatever **Dao** and **virtue** accomplish,
all things respond with awe and reverence.
The **Dao’s** grandeur, **virtue’s** nobility—
no summons is made, yet they ever act naturally.
The **Dao** does not call upon myriad things,
yet they always respond naturally, like the echo of a sound.
Hence, the **Dao** gives birth to them,
**virtue** nurtures them,
lengthens and fosters them,
fulfills and matures them,
covers and protects them.
The **Dao** does not merely give birth to myriad things—
it also lengthens, nurtures, fulfills, matures,
and covers to preserve their nature and life.
When a ruler governs a state or cultivates oneself,
one should act likewise.
To give birth without possession—
the **Dao** gives birth to myriad things,
yet does not claim ownership for its own use.
To act without reliance—
the **Dao’s** deeds are not done to demand reward.
To lengthen without slaughter—
the **Dao** lengthens and nurtures myriad things,
yet does not slaughter or harm for its own gain.
This is called **Mysterious Virtue**.
The **Dao’s** actions are **en** and **virtue**,
yet their mystery is dark and unseen.
—**Returning to the Root (the fifty-second)**

The world has a beginning,
and that beginning is the **Dao**.
The **Dao** is called the "mother of the world."
Since one knows its mother,
one must also know its child;

Having known the **Dao**,

Having known the singular,

Thus, one’s life is not endangered.
One’s body does not perish.
Close its **dui**—

Do not gaze recklessly.
Shut its **men**—

open the eyes,

Fulfill its affairs—

Benefit the desires.
Then, one’s life is not in peril.
Calamity and chaos arise.

to employ the eyes’ light outward,

meaning to restore the light inward,
so that the **spirit** does not leak away.
No calamity befalls the body—
by inwardly preserving the **spirit**,

This is called **Habitual Practice**.
If a person can act thus,
it is called **practicing and habituating the Way**.

"Let me be clearly aware of governance,

**Jie**, the great.

personally embodying the transformation of non-action."

**Yòu**, alone.
Alone fearing the loss of **Dao** through action.

The great **Dao** is most even,
**yí**, plain and easy.
