「Yet the people love crooked paths.
Crooked paths—unrighteous, not upright or just—
though the great Dao is most plain and easy,
the people prefer to follow these crooked paths.

The court is most extravagant,
with towering pavilions and grand halls,
palaces and chambers adorned.
Fields lie most untended,
agriculture neglected,
plowing and tilling forsaken while seasons pass.
Granaries lie most empty,
grains spoiled and wasted,
the nation lacks provision.

They adorn themselves in fine embroidery,
pursue ornate pretense,
value outward splendor.
They wear sharp blades,
praise strength and vigor,
pursue martial prowess and wasteful excess.
They glut themselves with food and drink,
wealth overflowing,
desires insatiable,
yet never content—
this is called **deceptive display**.

When the common folk lack while the ruler has excess,
it is due to **plunder and theft**.
In **deceptive display**, one flaunts attire and conduct,
unaware that death may come,
families may crumble,
and kin may perish along with them.
**Deceptive display** is not the Dao, is it?

If a ruler acts thus,
this is not the Dao.
The words *"is it not?"* are an expression of lament.

—**Habitual Practice (the fifty-fourth)**

**Established virtue does not falter**,
*Established*—to stand firm.
Virtue established through the Dao in one’s person and nation
cannot be shaken or uprooted.

**Embraced virtue does not depart**,
Virtue embraced through the Dao in spirit and qi
will never be abandoned or released.

Their descendants’ sacrifices will never cease.
If a person’s descendants practice the Dao thus,
they achieve **long life without death**,
enduring through generations,
their ancestral temples never without offerings.

Practiced in the person,
its **virtue/power** becomes true;
Practiced in the person, the Dao
nurtures **qi** and preserves the **spirit**,
extending life and prolonging years.
If its **virtue/power** is such,
then one becomes a **True Person**.

Practiced in the family,
its **virtue/power** overflows;
Practiced in the family, the Dao
brings forth a father’s tenderness and a son’s filial piety,
a brother’s kindness and a younger sibling’s obedience,
a husband’s trust and a wife’s rectitude.
If its **virtue/power** is such,
then blessings abound for future generations.

Practiced in the village,
its **virtue/power** grows long;
Practiced in the village, the Dao
honors and respects the elders,
loves and nurtures the young,
and instructs the foolish and ignorant.
If its **virtue/power** is such,
then none are left uncovered by its influence.

Practiced in the state,
its **virtue/power** becomes abundant;
Practiced in the state, the Dao
makes the ruler **sage-like** and ministers **loyal**,
**ren** and **yi** arise naturally,
rituals and music flourish of their own accord,
governance is smooth without effort.
If its **virtue/power** is such,
then its blessings are plentiful.

Practiced throughout the world,
its **virtue/power** becomes universal.
A ruler who practices the Dao throughout the world
acts without speaking, governs without teaching,
and the people respond as shadows follow their forms.
If its **virtue/power** is such,
then it may be called **universal and broad**.

Thus, observing the person with the person,
one observes a **Dao-practicing** person against a **non-Dao-practicing** person—
who perishes, who survives?

Observing the family with the family,
one observes a **Dao-practicing** family against a **non-Dao-practicing** family.

Observing the village with the village,
one observes a **Dao-practicing** village against a **non-Dao-practicing** village.

Observing the state with the state,
one observes a **Dao-practicing** state against a **non-Dao-practicing** state.

Observing the world with the world,
one observes a **Dao-practicing** ruler against a **non-Dao-practicing** ruler.
How do I know this to be so?
By this.

Laozi spoke: *"How do I know the world thrives when the Dao is practiced,
and declines when the Dao is abandoned?"*
By observing these five matters, one knows it.

—**Mysterious Correspondence (the fifty-fifth)**

The depth of **virtue/power** that is contained,
*Contained*—the richness of virtue held within.
Like an infant.

The **spirit** and **clarity** protect and bless those who contain virtue,
as parents cherish an infant.

Venomous creatures do not sting,
bees and wasps, snakes and insects—
none sting.
Fierce beasts do not seize,
raptors do not strike.
An infant is not harmed by things,
things do not harm it.
Thus, in the **Great Peace** era,
people, regardless of rank,
all possess **ren** hearts.
Thorny things return to their source;
venomous creatures do not harm people.
Though bones are weak and sinews are soft,
its grip is firm—
an infant’s sinews and bones are soft and weak,
yet it holds things with unyielding strength,
for its intent is focused and its heart does not stray.

It does not know the joining of male and female yet grows fierce,
the peak of **essence**.
An infant, unaware of male-female union,
yet its **yin** rises in anger—
this is due to the abundance of **essence-qi**.

It cries all day yet its throat does not grow hoarse,
the utmost **harmony**.
An infant, from morning till evening,
cries without ceasing,
its voice unchanging—
this is due to the abundance of **harmonious qi**.

To know **harmony** is to know the **constant Dao**,
*Constant*—ever-present, unchanging.
If a person knows the **harmonious qi**’s softness and benefit,
then they understand the Dao’s constancy.

To know the **constant Dao** is to know **clarity**,
*Clarity*—enlightenment, insight.
If a person knows and follows the Dao’s constancy,
then day by day they attain **clarity** in its mysteries.

**Beneficial life** is called **auspicious**,
*Auspicious*—the Dao’s blessing.
Speaking of life that grows evermore,
day by day expanding and strengthening.
The heart directs **qi**—this is called **strength**.
If the heart is focused, gentle, and harmonious,
**qi** and **spirit** are firmly rooted within,
so the form is soft.
But if the heart instead allows **false desires** to act,
then **harmonious qi** departs from the center,
and the form grows evermore **rigid and strong**.

—**Mysterious Virtue (the fifty-sixth)**

Things grow strong then age,
this is called **not the Dao**.
When all things reach their peak of vigor,
they wither and grow old—
old, they cannot attain the Dao.

**Not the Dao** leads to early decline.
Those who do not attain the Dao
die young.

The wise do not speak,
the wise value **practicing the Dao** over words.
The talkative lack wisdom,
many words bring many troubles—
four horses cannot outrun the tongue.

Block its **mouth**,
close its **gate**,
*Block*—to stop at the source.
*Close*—to shut the door.
To **block** and **close** is to sever its origin.

Dull its sharpness,
when desires are keen,
one should reflect on the Dao’s **non-action** to blunt them.

Loosen its tangles,
*tangles*—knots of grudges that never unwind.
One should reflect on the Dao’s **simplicity** to unravel them.

Harmonize its brightness,
though one may have solitary insight,
one should harmonize it to prevent dazzlement.
Equalize its dust,
one should not distinguish oneself.
This is called **mysterious unity**.
*Mysterious*—heavenly, profound.
If a person can act thus,
this is called **aligning with Heaven’s Dao**.

Thus, it cannot be **close**,
not delighting in honor and glory,
yet standing firm in sorrow.
Nor can it be **distant**;
*Distant*—detached, estranged.
With **calm intent** and **no desires**,
one bears no grudges against others.

The Way cannot be grasped for **gain**—
the body does not crave wealth and rank,
the palate does not lust after the five flavors.

Nor can it be grasped for **harm**—
it does not contend with the greedy for profit,
nor does it vie with the bold for strength.

It cannot be made **exalted**—
it does not serve as a ruler in chaotic times,
nor does it occupy a position under a tyrannical lord.

Nor can it be made **lowly**—
it does not grow arrogant through power,
nor does it bow its will in defeat.

Thus, it is **noble beyond the world**.
Its virtue is such that
kings cannot make it their subject,
lords cannot bend it to their will.
It floats with the world, rising and falling,
preserving itself while avoiding harm—
thus, it is **noble beyond the world**.

To govern the realm with **rectitude**—
*rectitude*, the utmost.
Heaven appoints those of upright conduct
to rule with perfect governance.

To wage war with **strategy**—
*strategy*, deceit.
Heaven appoints those skilled in guile
to command the armies.

To seize the world through **non-action**—
Heaven entrusts those who act with effortless ease
to rule the world as its sovereign.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this—
*this*, the present.
Laozi said:
How do I know Heaven’s intent is so?
By what is seen today.

**Pure Wind**, the Fifty-Seventh.

The world abounds in taboos and prohibitions,
yet the people grow ever poorer.
The world speaks of the sovereign.
Taboos are restrictions and bans.
Too many decrees breed deceit,
too many prohibitions spawn guile below—
thus, mutual harm and poverty arise.

The people multiply clever tools,
and the state grows ever more confused.
Clever tools are *power* and influence.
When the people wield too much power,
those who watch grow dazzled by sight,
those who listen grow bewildered by sound—
superior and inferior grow estranged,
and thus the state falls into chaos.

The people multiply in skill and artifice,
and strange adornments flourish.
The people speak of the ruler and the great lords.
Multiplying in skill means carving palaces and halls,
engraving robes and adornments.
Strange adornments grow ever more extravagant—
those below emulate those above,
decorating with gold and jade,
embroidering with silk and dyes,
ever more excessive each day.

Fine and desirable things grow ever more prominent,
and thieves and robbers multiply.
Fine and desirable things are luxuries.
When luxuries flourish and are displayed openly,
farming is neglected,
hunger and cold draw near—
thus, thieves and robbers multiply.

Therefore, the Sage says:
*"I act with non-action, and the people transform themselves.*
The Sage speaks: *I cultivate the Dao and align with Heaven,
making no alterations or innovations,
yet the people transform themselves naturally.*

*I love stillness, and the people become upright.*
The Sage speaks: *I cherish tranquility,
speaking not, teaching not,
yet the people all become loyal and true.*

*I engage in no affairs, and the people grow rich.*
Without forced labor or conscription,
the people settle into their work—
thus, they all grow rich.

*I desire nothing, and the people return to simplicity.*
I constantly desire nothing,
rejecting ornamentation and finery,
wearing modest attire—
the people follow my simplicity.

*I abandon emotions, and the people grow pure.*
The Sage speaks: *I cultivate the Dao and uphold the True,
severing the Six Emotions,
and the people follow my purity."*

chunks.translated_text:
**Pure Transformation, the Fifty-Eighth**
Its governance is—
vast and profound, obscure yet dim,
as if without clarity.
Its people are pure and refined.

When governance is vast and profound,
the people become pure and refined,
rich and harmonious,
living in mutual affection.

When governance is meticulous and probing,
its teachings are swift and hidden—
words decided by the mouth,
hearings decided by the ear.
Its people grow weary and depleted.
When teachings are hasty and oppressive,
the people struggle to survive,
thus growing weary and depleted day by day.

Calamity! It is the foundation of fortune.
*Foundation* means *origin*.
When fortune arises from calamity,
those who encounter calamity repent their errors,
blame themselves,
and cultivate virtuous conduct along the Dao—
then calamity departs and fortune arrives.

Fortune! It is the seedbed of calamity.
Calamity lies hidden within fortune.
When one obtains fortune and becomes arrogant and licentious,
fortune departs and calamity arrives.

Who knows its limits?
Calamity and fortune generate each other—
who can know their ultimate end?

When the ruler lacks rectitude,
*lack* means *not*.
It means the ruler does not rectify himself—
then the state will perish.

Rectitude returns as deceit.
*Deceit* means *craftiness*.
When the ruler lacks rectitude,
even rectitude transforms beneath him into craftiness.

Virtue returns as hypocrisy.
Virtuous men all transform above into hypocritical omens.

The people’s confusion is long-standing.
It speaks of the ruler’s delusion and loss of rectitude
having endured for many days.

Thus the Sage is square yet does not cut,
The Sage practices rectitude to guide the people,
not to sever them.

He is frugal yet does not harm,
The Sage’s frugality is pure,
seeking to transform the people,
not to injure them.
Yet now it is not so—
rectifying oneself to harm others.

He is upright yet does not flaunt,
*Flaunt* means *proclaim*.
Though the Sage is upright,
he bends himself to others,
not proclaiming himself.

He shines yet does not dazzle.
Though the Sage possesses singular insight,
he remains as if dim,
not dazzling others with brilliance.

**Guarding the Dao, the Fifty-Ninth**
**Govern the People**
The ruler who governs the people
should serve the Dao of Heaven,
following the Four Seasons.

Nothing surpasses frugality.
*Frugality* means *love*.
The ruler who governs the state must love the people’s resources,
not indulging in extravagance.
The ruler who governs himself must love his vital essence,
not indulging in dissipation.

Only through frugality
does one attain early mastery.
*Early* means *prior*.
*Mastery* means *attainment*.
To love the people’s resources and vital essence alone
is to first attain the Dao of Heaven.

Early mastery is called accumulating virtue.
To first attain the Dao of Heaven
is to accumulate virtue within oneself.
Accumulating virtue means nothing remains unconquered.
*Conquer* means *overcome*.
To accumulate virtue within oneself
is to overcome all.
To overcome all means none know its limits.
To overcome all without limits
is to possess the state.
To possess the state without limits
is to endure long.
The state and the body are the same.
*Mother* refers to the Dao.
If one preserves the Dao within the body,
so that vital essence is not exhausted
and the Five Spirits are not tormented,
then one may endure long.

This is called deep roots and firm foundations.
If one takes *qi* as root and essence as foundation,
like a tree—if roots are not deep, it will be uprooted;
if the foundation is not firm, it will fall—
it speaks of deeply guarding one’s *qi*
and firmly preserving one’s essence,
so that none may leak away.

This is the Dao of longevity and enduring vision.
Those with deep roots and firm foundations
embody the Dao of longevity and enduring vision.

chunks.original_text: 治大国如江海者下流，不逆细微。 天下之交， 大国，天下之士民之所交会。 天下之牝。 牝者，阴类也。 柔谦和而不倡也。 牝常以静胜牡， 女所以能屈於男，阴胜阳#2，以安静不先求之。 以静为下。 阴道以安。 故大国以下小国，则取小国； 能谦下之，则常有之。 小国以下大国，则聚大国。 此言国无小大，能执谦畜人，则无过生。 故或下以取，或下以聚。 下者谓大国以下小国。 小国以下大国，更以义相取也。 大国不过欲兼畜人， 大国不失下，则兼并小国而牧畜之。 小国不过欲入事人。 欲为臣仆。 夫两者各得其所欲，故大者宜为下。 大国小国各欲得其所欲，大国尤宜谦下也。 为道第六十二 道者，万物之奥， 奥，藏也。 道以万物之藏，无所不容也。 善人之宝， 善人以道，为身之宝，不敢违也。 不善人之所保。 道者，不善人之所保倚也。 遭患逢急，犹能知自悔卑柔也。 美言可以市， 美言可以市者，夫市交易而退，不相宜售善言美语，求者欲疾得，卖者欲疾售。 尊行可以加人。 加，别也。 人有尊贵之行，可以别异於凡人，未足以尊道。 人之不善，何弃之有？ 人虽不善，当以道化之。 盖三皇之前，无有弃民，德化淳也。 故立天子，置三公， 欲使教化不善之人。 虽有拱璧以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 虽有美玉，以先驷马而至，不如坐进此道也。 古之所贵此道者，何不日求以得， 古之所以贵此道者，不日日远行求索，近得之於身。 有罪以免耶？ 有罪者谓遭乱世，暗君妄行刑诛，修道则可以解死厄，免於众耶。 故为天下贵。 道德洞远，无不覆济，全身治国，恬然无为，故可以为天下贵。 恩始第六十三 为无为，

「To govern a great state as the rivers and seas flow downward,
it does not resist the smallest currents.
The world’s convergence rests in great states,
where the world’s people gather and assemble.

The world’s *yin*—
*Yin* is the category of the receptive.
Soft, humble, yielding, yet not aggressive.
*Yin* always overcomes *yang* through stillness,
for the female bends beneath the male,
*yin* triumphs over *yang*#2,
by remaining tranquil and never seeking first.

To be still is to be lowly.
The *Dao* of *yin* brings stability.
Thus, when a great state humbles itself before small states,
it takes them;
when it remains humble and yielding,
it keeps them.
When a small state humbles itself before a great state,
it is gathered under it.
This shows that states, great or small,
if they grasp humility and nurture others,
will never err.

Thus, sometimes one humbles to take,
sometimes to gather.
To humble means for the great state to yield to the small,
and for the small state to yield to the great,
each taking what is rightfully theirs.
The great state seeks only to encompass and nurture others.
If the great state does not lose its humility,
it will swallow and tend to the small states.
The small state seeks only to serve others,
to become their subjects and servants.
When both obtain what they desire,
the greater should indeed humble itself.
The great state and the small state each seek what they desire,
but the great state should especially humble itself.

**Section 62: The Way**

The *Dao* is the hidden essence of all things—
*Essence*, meaning what is stored within.
The *Dao* as the hidden storehouse of all things,
contains all without exclusion.

The treasure of the virtuous,
the virtuous use the *Dao* as their personal treasure,
daring not to defy it.
The refuge of the unvirtuous,
the *Dao* is the unvirtuous’ support and reliance.
Even in calamity or urgency,
they may yet know to repent, humble, and yield.

Fine words can be sold—
Fine words can be sold: in trade, one exchanges and withdraws,
but does not persist in selling virtuous speech or sweet words.
The buyer desires swift acquisition,
the seller desires swift sale.
Noble conduct can be bestowed upon others.
*Bestow*, meaning to distinguish.
When a person’s conduct is noble and distinguished,
it is not yet sufficient to honor the *Dao*.
What should one discard of those who are unvirtuous?
Even the unvirtuous should be transformed by the *Dao*.
Before the Three Sovereigns, there were no abandoned people—
their virtue and transformation were pure.
Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven and the Three Ministers,
it is to teach and transform the unvirtuous.
Even if one presents a jade tablet before four horses,
it is not as good as sitting and offering this *Dao*.
Even if one presents fine jade with four horses,
it is not as good as sitting and offering this *Dao*.
Why did the ancients value this *Dao* so highly?
Why not seek it daily to obtain it?
The ancients valued this *Dao* not by daily distant journeys to seek it,

Can it free one from guilt?

under tyrannical rulers who unjustly mete out punishment—
practicing the *Dao* can dissolve death’s peril,
saving one from the masses.
Thus, it is held in highest esteem by the world.

The *Dao* and *virtue* are profound and far-reaching,
covering and aiding all without exception,
preserving the self and governing the state,
serene and effortless—
thus, it can be held in highest esteem by the world.

chunks.original_text: 因成修故，无所改作。 事无事， 预设备，除烦省事。 味无味。 深思远虑，味道意也。 大小多少， 陈其戒令也。 欲大反小，欲多反少，自然之道也。 报怨以德。 修道行善，绝祸於未萌也。 图难於其易， 欲图难事#3，当於易时未及成也。 为大於其细。 欲为大事，必作於小，祸乱从小来也。 天下难事必作於易，天下大事必作於细。 是以大人终不为大， 处谦虚也。 故能成其大。 天下共归之也。 夫轻诺必寡信， 不重言也。 多易必多难。 不慎患也。 是以圣人犹难之， 圣人动作举事，犹进退重难之，欲塞其故源也。 故终无难。 圣人终身无患难之事，由避害深也。 守微第六十四 其安易持， 治身治国，安静者易守持。 其未兆易谋， 情欲祸患，未有形兆时，易谋止也。 其脆易破， 祸乱未至萌，情欲未见於色，如脆弱易破除也。 其微易散。 其未彰着，微小易散去也。 为之於未有， 欲有所为，当於未有萌芽之时，塞其端。 治之於未乱。 治身治国，於未乱之时，当预闭其门。 合抱之木，生於毫末； 从小成大。 九层之台，起於累土； 从卑至高。 千里之行，始於足下。 从近至远。 为者败之， 有为於事，废於自然； 有为於义，废於仁，有为於色，废於精神也。 执者失之。 执利遇患，执道全身，坚持不得，推让还及。 圣人无为，故无败； 圣人不为文华，不为己利，不为残贼，故无坏败。 无执，故无失。 圣人有德以教愚，有财以与贫，无所执藏，故无所失於人。 民之从事，常於几成而败之， 从，为也。 民之为事，常於功德几成而贪位好名，而奢泰盈满，而自败之也。 慎终如始，则无败事。 终当如始，不致懈怠。 是以圣人欲不欲#4， 圣人欲人所不欲也。 人欲彰显，圣人欲韬光； 人欲文饰，圣人欲质朴； 人欲於色，圣人欲於德。 不贵难得之货； 圣人不眩晃为服玩，不贱石贵玉也。 学不学， 圣人学人所不能学。 人学智诈，圣人学自然； 人学治世，圣人学治身守道真也。 复众人之所过。 众人学问皆反也，过本为末#5，过实为华。 复之者，使反本实者也。 以辅万物之自然， 教人反本实者，欲以辅助万物自然之性#6。 而不敢为。 圣人动作因循，不敢有所造为，恐离本也。 淳德第六十五 古之善为道者， 说古之善以道治身及治国者。 非以明民， 不以道教民明智巧诈也。 将以愚之。 将以道德教民，使质朴不诈伪。 民之难治，以其智多。 民之不可治理者，以其智太多，必为巧伪。 以智治国，国之贼； 使智惠之人理国之政事，必远道德，妄作祸福，而为国之贼也。 不以智治国，国之福。 不使智惠之人治国之政事，则民守正直，不为邪饰，上下相亲，君臣同力，故为国之福也。 知此两者，亦楷式。 两者谓智不智也。 常能知智者贼，不智者福，是治身治国之法式也。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 玄，天也。 能知治身治国之法式，是谓与天同德也。 玄德深矣远矣， 玄德之人深不可测，远不可极也。 与物反矣， 玄德之人与万物反异，万物欲益己，玄德欲施与人也。 然后乃至大顺。 玄德与万物反异，故能至大顺。 大顺者，天理也。 后己第六十六 江海所以能为百谷王者，以其善下之， 江海以卑下，故众流归之，若民归就於王也。 故能为百谷王。 直以就下，故能为百谷王。

绝祸於未萌也。
cuts off calamity before it takes root.

图难於其易，
plotting for difficulty in its moments of ease—
欲图难事#3，
if one wishes to master a difficult task,
当於易时未及成也。
one must begin when it is still simple and not yet fully formed.

为大於其细。
To achieve the grand from the minute—
欲为大事，
if one seeks to accomplish great deeds,
必作於小，
one must first establish them in small matters—
祸乱从小来也。
for calamities arise from the small.

天下难事必作於易，
the most difficult tasks must be undertaken when they are still easy;
天下大事必作於细，
the greatest undertakings must begin with the slightest efforts.

是以大人终不为大，
thus, the great sage never seeks to do great things—
处谦虚也。
he remains in humility and modesty;
故能成其大。
therefore, he achieves true greatness.

天下共归之也。
All under heaven willingly submit to him.

夫轻诺必寡信，
he who makes light promises will rarely be trusted—
不重言也。
for he does not take his words seriously.

多易必多难。
What is overly facile will inevitably lead to many hardships—
不慎患也。
for he does not guard against misfortune.

是以圣人犹难之，
thus, the sage still regards difficulty as such—
圣人动作举事，
when he acts or undertakes matters,
犹进退重难之，
he weighs the forward and backward steps with grave deliberation,
欲塞其故源也。
seeking to block its origins.

故终无难。
Therefore, he ultimately faces no difficulty.

圣人终身无患难之事，
The sage’s entire life is free from calamity and hardship—
由避害深也。
for he avoids harm with profound insight.

守微第六十四
**Chapter 64: Holding to the Subtle**

其安易持，
its stability is easy to uphold—
治身治国，
for governing oneself and the state,
安静者易守持。
stability is the simplest to maintain.

其未兆易谋，
its unmanifested state is easy to plan for—
情欲祸患，
when passions and calamities have not yet taken form,
未有形兆时，
easily countered in their nascent stages.

其脆易破，
its fragility is easy to shatter—
祸乱未至萌，
when calamities have not yet sprouted,
情欲未见於色，
and passions have not yet appeared in deeds,
如脆弱易破除也。
they are like brittle things, easily dispelled.

其微易散。
Its subtlety is easy to disperse—
其未彰着，
before it becomes prominent,
微小易散去也。
the small and subtle can be easily scattered.

为之於未有，
Act upon it before it exists—
欲有所为，
if there is something to be done,
当於未有萌芽之时，
one must intervene when its roots have not yet taken hold,
塞其端。
blocking its onset.

治之於未乱。
Govern it before disorder arises—
治身治国，
for governing oneself and the state,
於未乱之时，
when disorder has not yet emerged,
当预闭其门。
one must preemptively close the door to it.

合抱之木，生於毫末；
A tree thick enough to encircle with both arms begins as a tiny sprout—
从小成大。
from small to great.

九层之台，起於累土；
A nine-tiered platform rises from a pile of earth—
从卑至高。
from low to high.

千里之行，始於足下。
A journey of a thousand *li* begins beneath one’s feet—
从近至远。
from near to far.

为者败之，
Those who act will fail—
有为於事，
when they act upon affairs,
废於自然；
they go against the *Dao* of nature;
有为於义，
when they act upon *virtue*,
废於仁，
they lose *ren* (benevolence);
有为於色，
when they act upon appearances,
废於精神也。
they lose *shen* (spirit).

执者失之。
Those who grasp will lose—
执利遇患，
when they cling to gain, they meet misfortune;
执道全身，
when they cling to the *Dao*, they preserve themselves—
坚持不得，
yet if they hold fast without yielding,
推让还及。
they may still fall back into harm.

圣人无为，
The sage acts without action—
故无败；
thus, he faces no failure;
圣人不为文华，
the sage does not indulge in superficial adornments,
不为己利，
nor does he seek personal gain,
不为残贼，
nor does he act for violence or plunder—
故无坏败。
thus, he faces no ruin or defeat.

无执，
Without grasping—
故无失。
he loses nothing.

圣人有德以教愚，
The sage has *virtue* to teach the ignorant,
有财以与贫，
and wealth to give to the poor—
无所执藏，
yet he does not cling to anything,
故无所失於人。
thus, he loses nothing to others.

民之从事，
The people’s undertakings—
常於几成而败之，
often fail when nearly complete—
从，为也。
*From* means *to act*.
民之为事，
When the people act upon affairs,
常於功德几成而贪位好名，
they often, when *virtue* and merit are nearly achieved,
covet rank and favor,
而奢泰盈满，
indulge in extravagance and excess,
而自败之也。
and thus bring ruin upon themselves.

慎终如始，
To be cautious at the end as at the beginning—
则无败事。
then there will be no failed undertakings.

终当如始，
The end must be as the beginning—
不致懈怠。
without slackening.

是以圣人欲不欲#4，
Thus, the sage desires what others do not—
圣人欲人所不欲也。
the sage desires what people do not desire.

人欲彰显，
People desire prominence and display—
圣人欲韬光；
the sage desires to conceal his brilliance;
人欲文饰，
people desire ornamentation and embellishment—
圣人欲质朴；
the sage desires simplicity and plainness;
人欲於色，
people desire beauty in form—
圣人欲於德。
the sage desires *virtue*.

不贵难得之货；
He does not value rare and hard-to-obtain goods—
圣人不眩晃为服玩，
the sage does not dazzle himself with adornments,
不贱石贵玉也。
nor does he demean stone while elevating jade.

学不学，
To learn what others cannot learn—
圣人学人所不能学。
the sage learns what people cannot learn.

人学智诈，
People learn cunning and deceit—
圣人学自然；
the sage learns the *Dao* of nature;
人学治世，
people learn to govern the world—
圣人学治身守道真也。
the sage learns to govern himself and uphold the true *Dao*.

复众人之所过。
To return to what people have erred upon—
众人学问皆反也，
the learning of the masses is all inverted,
过本为末#5，
error is the superficial outcome,
过实为华。
and ornamentation is the falsehood.

复之者，
To restore—
使反本实者也。
is to make them return to the true essence.

以辅万物之自然，
To aid the natural *Dao* of all things—
教人反本实者，
teaching people to return to their true nature,
欲以辅助万物自然之性#6。
seeking to assist the inherent *Dao* of all things.

而不敢为。
Yet he does not dare to act—
圣人动作因循，
the sage follows the natural course of things,
不敢有所造为，
not daring to fabricate or impose,
恐离本也。
for fear of straying from the true *Dao*.

淳德第六十五
**Chapter 65: Pure *Virtue***

古之善为道者，
The ancients who excelled in practicing the *Dao*—
说古之善以道治身及治国者。
speak of those who used the *Dao* to govern themselves and the state.

非以明民，
Not to enlighten the people—
不以道教民明智巧诈也。
for he does not teach the people the *Dao* of cleverness and deceit.

将以愚之。
But to make them simple—
将以道德教民，
he uses *Dao* and *virtue* to teach the people,
使质朴不诈伪。
so they remain plain and unadulterated.

民之难治，
The people are difficult to govern—
以其智多。
because their cleverness is excessive.

民之不可治理者，
The people who cannot be governed—
以其智太多，
because their cleverness is too great,
必为巧伪。
they will inevitably resort to artifice and deceit.

以智治国，国之贼；
To govern the state with cleverness is to be its thief—
使智惠之人理国之政事，
when clever and cunning individuals manage state affairs,
必远道德，
they will inevitably drift from *Dao* and *virtue*,
妄作祸福，
recklessly creating both blessings and misfortunes,
而为国之贼也。
and thus become thieves to the state.

不以智治国，国之福。
To not govern the state with cleverness is its blessing—
不使智惠之人治国之政事，
when one does not allow clever and cunning individuals to manage state affairs,
则民守正直，
the people uphold sincerity,
不为邪饰，
they do not engage in deceitful adornment,
上下相亲，
superior and inferior are harmonious,
君臣同力，
ruler and subjects work in concert—
故为国之福也。
thus, it is a blessing for the state.

知此两者，亦楷式。
To know these two principles is to grasp the model—
两者谓智不智也。
these two refer to the use and non-use of cleverness.

常能知智者贼，不智者福，
To always recognize that cleverness is a thief and simplicity a blessing—
是治身治国之法式也。
this is the method for governing oneself and the state.

常知楷式，
To always know the model—
是谓玄德。
is called *xuan* (mysterious) *virtue*.

玄，天也。
*Xuan* is the *Dao* of heaven.

能知治身治国之法式，
To know the methods of governing oneself and the state—
是谓与天同德也。
is to be in accord with the *virtue* of heaven.

玄德深矣远矣，
This *xuan* *virtue* is profound and distant—
玄德之人深不可测，
those with *xuan* *virtue* are deep beyond measure,
远不可极也。
and far beyond reach.

与物反矣，
They go against the nature of things—
玄德之人与万物反异，
those with *xuan* *virtue* are contrary to all things,
万物欲益己，
for all things seek to benefit themselves,
玄德欲施与人也。
while *xuan* *virtue* seeks to give to others.

然后乃至大顺。
Only then do they attain great harmony—
玄德与万物反异，
for *xuan* *virtue* is contrary to all things,
故能至大顺。
thus, they reach great harmony.

大顺者，天理也。
Great harmony is the *Dao* of heaven.

后己第六十六
**Chapter 66: The Sage Comes After Others**

江海所以能为百谷王者，
The rivers and seas are able to be the sovereigns of all the valleys—
以其善下之，
because they are good at being lowly—
江海以卑下，
the rivers and seas are humble and lowly,
故众流归之，
thus, all streams flow to them,
若民归就於王也。
as people naturally gather to their ruler.

故能为百谷王。
Thus, they are sovereigns of all the valleys.

直以就下，
Straightforwardly, they are lowly—
故能为百谷王。」
thus, they are able to be sovereigns of all the valleys.

under tyrannical rulers who unjustly mete out punishment—

The *Dao* and *virtue* are profound and far-reaching,
covering and aiding all without exception,
preserving the self and governing the state,
serene and effortless—

chunks.original_text: 是以圣人欲上民， 欲在民之上也。 必以言下之； 法江海，处谦虚。 欲先民， 欲在民之前也。 必以身后之。 先人而后己也。 是以圣人处民上而不重， 圣人在民上为主，不以尊贵虐下，故民戴仰，不以为重。 处前而民不害， 圣人在民前，不以光明蔽后，民亲之若父母，无有伤害之心。 是以天下乐推而不厌。 圣人恩深爱厚，视民如赤子，故天下乐共推进以为主，无有厌之也。 以其不争， 天下无厌圣人之时，是由圣人不与人争先后也。 故天下莫能与之争。 言人皆争於有为，无有争於无为也。 三宝第六十七 天下皆谓我大，似不肖。 老子言：天下皆谓我德大，我则佯愚似不肖。 夫唯大，故似不肖。 夫自名德大者，为身之害，故佯愚似若不肖。 无所分别，无所割截，不贱人而自贵。 若肖久矣， 肖，善，谓辩惠也。 若大辩惠之人，身自高贵，行察察之政，所从来久矣。 其细也夫。 言辩惠者唯如小人，非长者。 我有三宝，持而保之： 老子言：我有三宝，抱持而保倚之。 一曰慈， 爱百姓如赤子。 二曰俭， 赋敛若取之於己也。 三曰不敢为天下先。 执谦退，不为倡始也。 夫慈，故能勇； 先以仁慈，故乃勇於忠孝。 俭，故能广； 天子身能节俭，故民日用广矣。 不敢为天下先，故能成器长。 成器长谓得道人也。 我能为道人之长也。 今舍其慈且勇， 今世人舍慈仁，但为勇武。 舍其俭且广， 舍其俭约，但为奢泰。 舍其后且先； 舍其后己，但务先人。 死矣。 所行如此，动入死道。 夫慈，以战则胜，以守则固。 夫慈仁者，百姓亲附，并心一意，故以战则胜敌，以守卫则坚固。 天将救之，以善以慈卫之。 天将救助善人，必与慈仁之性，使能自营助也。 配天第六十八 古之善为士者不武， 言贵道德不好武力。 善战者不怒， 善以道战者，禁邪於心胸，绝祸於未萌，无所诛怒也。 善胜敌者不与争， 善以道胜敌者，附近以仁，来远以德，不与敌争而敌自服。 善用人者为下。 善用人自辅者，当为人执谦下。 是谓不争之德， 谓上为之下也#7。 是乃不与人争斗，乃是道德。 是谓用人之力， 能身为人下，是谓用人之力也。 是谓配天， 能行此者，德配天也。 古之极也。 是乃古之极要道也。 玄用第六十九 用兵有言： 陈用兵之道。 老子疾时用兵，故托己设其义。 吾不敢为主 主，先也。 我不敢先举兵。 而为客， 客者，和而不倡兵，当承天而后动。 不敢进寸而退尺。 侵人境界，利人财宝为进。 闭门守城为退也。 是谓行无行， 彼遂不止，为天下贼，虽行诛之，不行执也。 攘无臂， 虽有大怒者，无臂可攘。 仍无敌， 虽欲行仍引之心，若无敌可仍。 执无兵。 虽欲执持之，若无兵刃可持用也。 何者？ 伤彼之民罹罪於天，遭於不道之君，愍忍伤丧之痛也。 祸莫大於轻敌， 夫祸乱之害莫大於欺轻敌家，侵取不休，轻战而贪财宝也。 轻敌几丧吾宝。 几，近．也一宝，身也。 轻欺敌家，近丧身也。 故抗兵相加， 两敌战也。 则一反胜也已。 哀者慈仁，士卒不远於己。 知虽第七十 吾言甚易知，甚易行。

**Chapter 67: The Three Treasures**

Thus, the Sage desires to be above the people—
to be above them in position—
yet must speak humbly to them;
following the rivers and seas,
dwelling in modesty and humility.
To lead the people—
to be before them in action—
he must place himself behind them in deed.
He serves others before himself.

Therefore, the Sage, though above the people,
does not weigh them down;
though he is their sovereign,
he does not oppress them with his exalted status,
so the people revere him without feeling burdened.
He stands before them without harming them;
though he leads, he does not blind them with his brilliance,
so the people love him as they would their parents,
with no thought of harm.
Thus, all under heaven joyfully promote him without tiring.
The Sage’s kindness is profound, his love vast—
he views the people as his own children—
so all under heaven willingly advance him as their leader,
never weary of it.
Because he does not contend,
all under heaven never tire of the Sage’s rule,
for he does not compete with others for precedence.
Thus, none can contend with him.
Men all contend in action,
but none contend in non-action.

**Chapter 68: Aligning with Heaven**

All under heaven call me great,
yet I seem unworthy.
The *Laozi* says:
*"All under heaven call me virtuous and great,
yet I feign foolishness and seem unworthy.
Only because I am truly great
do I seem unworthy.
He who boasts of his great virtue
brings harm to himself,
so I feign foolishness and seem unworthy.
I make no distinctions,
take no sides,
do not demean others while elevating myself.
If I were skilled for long,
skill would mean cleverness and cleverness is not the way of the noble.
The clever are like petty men,
not the virtuous.
I possess three treasures;
I hold and cherish them:
First, *ci*—
loving the people as my own children.
Second, *jian*—
taxing as if taking from oneself.
Third, not daring to lead all under heaven.
I practice humility and retreat,
never initiating action.
Because of *ci*, I am courageous;
first with benevolence, then with loyalty and filial piety.
Because of *jian*, I am expansive;
the Son of Heaven’s own frugality
makes the people’s daily lives abundant.
Because I do not dare lead all under heaven,
I am able to become the leader of those who follow the *Dao*.
To be the leader of those who follow the *Dao*—
this is to be the Sage.
Now, they abandon *ci* and courage,
abandon *jian* and abundance,
abandon humility and seek precedence—
this is the path of death.
He who acts thus
moves ever closer to ruin.
*Ci* in war brings victory,
in defense brings security.
The benevolent and kind
win the people’s devotion,
their hearts and minds united,
so in war they conquer the enemy,
in defense they stand firm.
Heaven aids them,
shielding them with goodness and kindness.
Heaven aids the virtuous,
endowing them with benevolence and kindness
to help themselves."

The *Laozi*’s words are easy to know,
easy to practice.

「The *Laozi* says: My words are few yet easy to know,
simple yet easy to practice.
Yet none under heaven can truly know them,
none can truly practice them.
People do not love softness and weakness,
but love strength and vigor.
Words have their source,
affairs have their rulers.
What I say has its root and origin,
affairs have their lords and subjects.
Those who do not understand this
are not without my virtue—
their hearts oppose mine.

Only the unknowing
are thus unable to know me.
For it is the unknowing of the world
that renders my *Dao* and virtue obscure,
that they do not see them outwardly.
I penetrate the subtle and reach the profound mysteries,
so the unknowing remain unknowing.
Few know me,
so I am honored by those who follow me.
Few, indeed, are those who know me,
so I am cherished by those who understand the *Dao*.
Thus, the Sage wears coarse robes while harboring precious *qi*.
Wearing coarse robes means he is slighted outwardly,
harboring precious *qi* means he is rich inwardly.
He conceals his treasure and virtue,
not displaying them to the world.

**Chapter 71: Knowing Illness**

To know the unknown is supreme;
to know that one knows and yet speak of the unknown—
this is the supreme *virtue*.
To not know yet claim to know—
this is an illness.
To know that one knows and yet speak of the unknown—
this is the illness of *virtue*.

Only the sickly are thus unable to be sick.
The Sage does not suffer from this arrogance of knowledge,
for he grieves that others do.
The Sage is not sick,
for he knows sickness—
thus he is not sick.
He pities others because of this,
so he does not fall ill himself.

It is said that the Sage harbors comprehensive knowledge,
yet presents it as unknown,
so that all under heaven may remain simple and upright,
each guarding their pure nature.

The petty do not understand this intent,
yet presumptuously act with the arrogance of knowledge
to make themselves known.
They harm their *spirit* inwardly,
shorten their lifespan and waste their years.

**Chapter 72: Loving Oneself**

If the people do not fear *threat*,
then great *threat* will come.
*Threat* is harm.
If people do not fear small harm,
then great harm will come—
even fearing death itself.

Those who fear should nurture their *spirit*,
align with Heaven and follow Earth.
They should not narrow their dwelling place—
meaning the heart houses the *spirit*,
and it must always be calm and gentle,
never tight or constricted.
They should not weary of their source of life—
for people live because they possess *spirit*,
leaning on the void, delighting in stillness and purity.
If their diet is unregulated,
if they indulge in desires and lusts,
if their minds are filled with depravity,
these actions will cut short their lives and scatter their *spirit*.

Only those who do not weary
are thus not wearied.
Only those who truly do not weary of their *spirit*
can wash away the filth of their hearts,
remain tranquil and content without desire,
so that their *spirit* resides within them
and is never exhausted.

Thus, the Sage knows himself—
knows his own gains and losses.
He does not display himself—
does not flaunt his virtue and beauty outwardly,
but keeps them hidden within.
He loves himself—
loves his body to preserve his *spirit* and *qi*.
He does not prize himself—
does not seek high rank or fame in the world.
So he abandons that and takes this.
He abandons self-display and self-prize,
takes self-knowledge and self-love.

**Chapter 73: Acting with Restraint**

To dare with boldness means death;
to dare with boldness yet act means death to one’s body.
To dare without boldness means life;
to dare without boldness yet act means life for one’s body.
To know these two things—
that is, to know boldness and restraint—
is to know what may profit or harm.
To preserve life is profit,
to destroy life is harm.
What Heaven abhors
is the act of forcefulness.
Who knows its reason?
Who can understand Heaven’s intent
and avoid transgressing it?
Thus, even the Sage finds it difficult.

The Sage’s *Dao* is difficult to practice,
let alone those without the Sage’s virtue
who attempt to act thus.
The *Dao* of Heaven
does not contend yet achieves victory,
does not speak yet responds well,
does not summon yet comes naturally.
It is vast yet good at planning.
Vast, indeed, is Heaven’s *Dao*,
yet it carefully considers human affairs,
rewarding good and punishing evil,
each receiving their due.

Heaven’s net is vast and wide,
though loose, it does not miss a thing.
Heaven’s web is vast and far-reaching,
though seemingly distant,
if it examines and judges the good and evil of people,
it will not fail to see them.

**Chapter 74: Restraining Punishment**

If the people do not fear death,
then the ruler’s punishments are too severe,
and the people have no hope of survival,
so they do not fear death.
If one harms their body through indulgence,
if they squander their wealth and lose their life,
then the people do not know what to fear.
Why impose death as a threat?

The ruler should ease punishments,
teach the people to abandon desires and profits.
Yet if they act with cunning,
I can seize and execute them—
who would dare resist?

The *Laozi* laments the times
when rulers do not first cultivate the people with *Dao* and virtue,
but instead first impose punishments.

There are always those who execute punishment—
those who execute punishment are Heaven,
standing high above, observing people’s transgressions.
Heaven’s net is vast and wide,
though loose, it does not miss a thing.
If one acts as Heaven’s substitute in punishment,
this is called substituting the great carpenter to hew.
Heaven’s *Dao* is most clear,
its judgment has fixed rules,
like the seasons—
spring generates, summer grows,
autumn harvests, winter stores,
the stars and constellations move in their courses—
to govern all with its fixed order.
If a ruler attempts to substitute for Heaven’s punishment,
it is like a clumsy artisan
substituting for the great carpenter to cut wood—
laboring yet achieving no purpose.

If one substitutes for the great carpenter to hew,
there will rarely be one who does not harm their hands.
If a ruler acts with punishments,
it is like a clumsy artisan
substituting for the great carpenter to cut wood—
they cannot achieve the proper square or round,
and only harm their own hands.
Those who substitute for Heaven’s punishment
do not understand its principles,
and instead suffer its retribution.

**Chapter 75: Harm from Greed**

chunks.translated_text:
「The people’s hunger arises
from the excessive taxes imposed by their rulers.
The reason the people suffer hunger and cold
is that their lords take too many taxes from below.
Thus, they hunger.

The people all emulate their rulers’ greed,
abandoning the Dao and defying virtue—
hence, the hunger.

The people’s difficulty in being governed
comes from their rulers’ meddling.
The people cannot be governed
because their lords have many desires
and delight in intervention.
Thus, they are hard to govern.

Because their lords meddle,
the people’s emotions and falsehoods
become difficult to govern.

The people’s recklessness with death
stems from their excessive pursuit of life.
Those who lightly risk death
do so because their obsession with life’s affairs
and greed for gain endangers themselves.
Thus, they treat death lightly.

By pursuing life too fervently,
they court their own demise.

Only those who do not fixate on life
are wiser than those who revere it.
Only those who solely do not fixate on life’s concerns—
who neither covet rank and honor
nor amass wealth and profit—
who neither the Son of Heaven can claim as subjects
nor lords can command as servants,
are wiser than those who revere life.

**Chapter 76: Admonish the Overbearing**
Human life is soft and frail,
for living beings are born with harmonious *qi*,
embracing vital spirit—
thus, they are soft and frail.

But in death, they become hard and strong.
When one dies, harmonious *qi* is exhausted,
vital spirit departs—
thus, they become hard and strong.

All things, grasses and trees,
are soft and pliable when alive,
for harmonious *qi* remains.
But when they die, they wither and decay,
for harmonious *qi* disperses.
Thus, the hard and strong are the remnants of death,
while the soft and frail are the essence of life.

From these two observations,
one knows that the hard and strong perish,
while the soft and frail endure.
Thus, a strong army cannot conquer,
for its might invites reckless slaughter,
spreading poison and resentment.
The weak overcome the strong—
thus, it cannot conquer.

A strong tree decays,
for its rigid branches and leaves
suffer from its own strength.
The strong lie below,
the weak rise above.
In cultivating things and achieving works,
great trees must be placed below,
small things above.
This is the natural effect of Heaven’s Dao—
suppressing the strong and upholding the weak.

**Chapter 77: The Dao of Heaven**
The Dao of Heaven is like drawing a bow.
Heaven’s Dao is subtle and profound,
and all things are likened to it.
The high are brought low,
the low are raised up,
the overabundant are diminished,
the deficient are supplied.
Speaking of a bow’s balance and adjustment as such,
it can then be used.

To bring the high low and the low high,
to diminish the strong and benefit the weak—
this is Heaven’s Dao.
Heaven’s Dao diminishes excess and supplements deficiency,
prioritizing moderation and harmony.
Human affairs are otherwise,
for human affairs oppose Heaven’s Dao,
diminishing the deficient to serve the excess.
Common folk diminish the poor to enrich the rich,
plunder the weak to empower the strong.
Who can truly use their excess to benefit all under Heaven?
Only those with the Dao.

The Sage acts yet does not claim,
bestowing virtue and blessings without expectation of return.
They achieve their purpose yet do not dwell in it,
for when their work is done,
they do not remain in their position.
They do not desire to be seen as virtuous,
for they do not wish others to know of their own virtue.
They conceal their deeds and do not dwell on honor,
fearing Heaven’s punishment for excess.
They trust in sincerity.

**Chapter 78: Trust in Integrity**
Water is the softest and weakest under Heaven,
for it adapts—
round when round, square when square—
contained, it stops;
unleashed, it flows.
Yet nothing can overcome it in attacking the hard and strong,
for water can embrace mountains and enclose hills,
erode iron and melt copper.
No force can conquer water yet achieve its purpose.
For nothing is as effortlessly powerful as water.

Thus, the soft overcomes the hard,
for the tongue is soft while the teeth are hard,
yet the teeth perish before the tongue.
The weak overcome the strong,
for water extinguishes fire,
and *yin* consumes *yang*.
All under Heaven know this,
yet few can act accordingly.
They shame humility and prefer strength,
thus the Sage says:
*"To bear the filth of a state*
*is to be called its sovereign."*
A ruler who endures their state’s impurities,
like the great rivers and seas that do not resist small streams,
can long preserve the altars of soil and grain,
and be the sovereign of a single state.

*"To bear the ill-fortune of a state*
*is to be called the King of all under Heaven."*
A ruler who takes blame upon themselves,
and bears the misfortunes of the people,
can then rule all under Heaven.

This is straight speech taken as reverse.」

chunks.original_text: 圣人虽治大国，犹以为小国，示俭约，不为奢泰。 民虽众，犹若寡乏，不敢劳。 使有什伯， 使民各有部曲什伯，贵贱不相犯也。 人之器而不用。 器谓农人之器。 而不用者，不征实夺民之时。 使民重死， 君能为民兴利除害，各得其所，则民重死而贪生也。 而不远徙。 政令不烦则安其业，故不远迁，其常处也。 虽有舟舆，无所乘之； 清静无为，不作烦华，不好出游娱。 虽有甲兵，无所陈之， 无怨恶於天下。 使民复结绳而用之。 去文反质，信无欺也。 甘其食， 甘其蔬食，不鱼食百姓也。 美其服， 美其恶衣，不贵五色也。 安其居， 安其茅茨，不好文饰之屋。 乐其俗。 乐其质朴之俗，不转移。 邻国相望，鸡犬之声相闻， 相去近也。 民至老死不相往来。 其无情欲。 显质第八十 信言不美， 信言者，如其实也。 不美者，朴且质也。 美言不信。 滋美之言者，孳孳之美辞。 不信者，饰伪多空虚也。 善者不辩， 善者，以道修身也。 不辩者，不文彩也。 辩者不善。 辩者，谓巧言也。 不善者，舌致患也。 土有玉，掘其山； 水有珠，浊其渊； 辩口多言者，亡其身也。 知者不博， 知者，谓知道之士。 不博者，守一元也。 博者不知。 博者，多见闻。 不知者，失要真也。 圣人不积， 圣人积德不积财，有德以教愚，有财以与贫也。 既以为人，己愈有； 既以为人施设德化，己愈有德。 既以与人，已愈多。 既以财贿布施与人，而财益多如日月之光，无有尽时。 天之道，利而不害； 天生万物，爱育之令长大#13，无所伤害。 圣人之道，为而不争。 圣人法天所施为化，功成事就，不与天下争功名，故能全其圣功。 道德真经注卷之四竟 #1此后影宋本尚有经文及注文：非其鬼不神，其神不伤人。 其鬼非无精神，邪不入正，不能伤自然之人。 #2阴胜阳：原作『胜阳阴』，据影宋本改。 #3欲图难事：『欲图』原脱，据影宋本加。 #4欲不欲：原本作『终不欲』，据影宋本改。 #5末：原本作『实』，据影宋本改。 #6自然之性：『性』字原脱，据影宋本加。 #7谓上为之下：原本『上』后衍『文』字，据影宋本删。 #8吾所言：『言』字原脱，据影宋本加。 #9运移：『移』字原脱，据影宋本加。 #10孰：此字原脱，据影宋本加。 #11磨铁销铜：『铁』原作『水』，据影宋本改。 #12刻契合符：原本『刻」前衍『刑』字，据影宋本删。 #13长大； 原本作『长天』，据影宋本改。
chunks.translated_text:
The Sage, though governing a great state,
still treats it as a small one,
demonstrating frugality,
not indulging in extravagance.
The people, though many,
are as if few and scarce,
daring not to labor them.
Let there be the *shí-bǎi* (units of ten and hundred),
so that each citizen has their *bùqū* (military divisions and civilian groups),
and the noble and humble do not encroach upon one another.
The farmer’s tools are kept,
yet not used to seize their time.

A ruler makes death precious to the people,
for when they bring benefit and remove harm,
each attains their due,
and the people value death over life.
Yet they do not move far away.
When governance is simple and orders few,
the people settle into their occupations,
thus they do not migrate far,
and remain in their steadfast homes.
Though there are boats and carriages,
they find no use for them;
in tranquility and non-action,
they shun frivolous adornments,
and do not delight in travel or amusement.
Though there are arms and armor,
they display them not,
and harbor no resentment toward all under Heaven.
The people return to using knotted cords for record-keeping.
Discarding artifice and reverting to simplicity,
they trust without deceit.

They find contentment in their food,
in the simple grains and vegetables,
not plundering the people for fish and luxuries.
They adorn their clothing,
in the plain and coarse garments,
not favoring the five bright hues.
They make their dwellings secure,
in humble thatched huts,
not indulging in ornate architecture.
They take joy in their customs,
in the plain and honest ways,
not altering them with foreign fashions.
Neighboring states are visible,
where the sounds of roosters and dogs intermingle,
for they are close at hand.
Yet the people, until old age and death,
do not visit one another.
This is their lack of desire for external things.

**Chapter Eighty: Plain Speech**
Plain speech is not adorned,
for plain speech is as it truly is.
Not adorned means it is unembellished and genuine.
Adorned speech is not plain,
for excessive ornamentation leads to hollow and deceitful words.
The virtuous do not argue,
for the virtuous cultivate the Dao in their conduct.
Not to argue means they do not indulge in rhetorical flourishes.
Those who argue are not virtuous,
for argumentative speech brings calamity.
The Sage does not hoard,
for the Sage accumulates virtue, not wealth,
teaching the ignorant with their virtue,
and aiding the poor with their riches.
When they give to others,
they themselves grow ever more abundant.
When they share with others,
they themselves grow ever more plentiful.
The Way of Heaven
is to benefit and not harm;
Heaven nurtures all things,
loving them to growth and maturity,
without injury.
The Sage’s Way
is to act without striving.
The Sage follows Heaven’s Way in their governance,
achieving their aims without contention,
and thus preserves their sacred virtue.

**End of the Fourth Scroll of the *Zhenjing* of Dao and Virtue.**

*(The following lines are present in the Song shadow copy but omitted here:)*
*"Not their spirits, but their ghosts do not harm,
for their ghosts are not without vitality;
evil cannot enter the virtuous,
and thus cannot harm those of natural disposition."*

A ruler who endures their state’s impurities,
like the great rivers and seas that do not resist small streams,
can long preserve the altars of soil and grain,
and be the sovereign of a single state.

*"To bear the ill-fortune of a state*
*is to be called the King of all under Heaven."*
A ruler who takes blame upon themselves,
and bears the misfortunes of the people,
can then rule all under Heaven.
